loans.name: Bernarda

texts.en:
My name is Bernarda, I have had my little market for 9 years and I have a good clientel. Since I was widowed, I dedicated myself to this store and my business grew. Now I generate earnings enough to cover the costs of my business and the expenses it takes to maintain good health.

Loan Use: cheeses, sodas, bread, eggs, milk, confectionaries and others. 

Mi nombre es Bernarda, tengo 9 años de tener mi mercadito del que tengo una buena clientela, desde que enviude me dedique a vender y mi negocio crecio, ahora me genera ingresos para suplir los gastos de mi negocio y los gastos para mantener una buena sallud.

loans.use: Compra de quesos, refrescos, pan, huevos, leche, confites y otros.

loans.name: Doris Patricia

texts.en:
My name is Doris Patricia, but everyone knows me as Paty. I have had my grocery store for five years, and it is located in my home. In this zone there are few businesses that exist, because of which I need to supply my store with products, in order to sell more and to have higher earnings that help me with family needs and those of the business.

Loan Use: Buying bread, eggs, churros, drinks, water, milk and others 

Me llamo Doris Patricia, todos me conocen como Paty, tengo cinco años de tener mi pulperia la que esta ubicada en mi casa de habitacion. En esta zona son pocos los negocios que existen, por lo que necesito surtir de productos para poder vender mas y por ende tener mejores ingresos que me ayudan con los compromisos familiares y del negocio.

loans.use: Compra de pan, huevos, churros, refrescos, agua, leche y otros.

payments.comment: Mis compras fueron mejores por la ayuda que me brindaron, ahora necesito mas capital para surtir nuevamente y ampliar mis ventas y mejorar mis ingresos, Gracias.

loans.name: Gladiz Isabel

texts.en:
I have had my small grocery store, located on one the the main roads to other communities, for five years. Everyone knows me to have good customer service and fair prices on all the products needed for basic consumption. I know that by stocking my store more, I can have higher earnings and can help my family in their studies.

Loan Use: Buying water, sodas, bread, over the counter drugs, eggs, cornmeal, coffee, sugar, rice and others

Tengo cinco años de tener una pequeña pulperia ubicada en uno de los principales desvios a otras comunidades, todos me conocen por darles un buen trato y precios accesibles en todos los productos de la canasta basica. Se que surtiendo mas mi negocio, puedo tener mejores ingresos y ayudar a mi familia en sus estudios.

loans.use: Compra de agua, refrescos, pan, medicamentos de uso comun, huevos, harina de maiz, cafe, azucar, arroz y otros.

payments.comment: Gracias a su ayuda pude hacer que mi negocio mejorara en ventas y en poder brindar a mis clientes buenos productos.

loans.name: Grime Pastora

texts.en:
My name is Grime, and I have had my grocery store for 9 years, which has grown with time, this business generates enough to cover the needs of my family and the studies of my three children.

Loan Use: Buying cheese, corn, beans, drinks, churros, flour, bread and others.

Me llamo Grime, tengo 9 años de tener mi pulperia la que ha crecido con el tiempo, este negocio me genera lo suficiente para suplir las necesidades de mi familia y los estudios de mis 3 hijos.

loans.use: Compra de queso, maiz, frijoles, maiz, refrescos, churros, harina, pan, y otros.

payments.comment: Por las ventas que han crecido he podido cancelar mi deuda antes de tiempo, ahora necesito capital fresco para iniciar a vender mas en este verano.

loans.name: Reina Margarita

texts.en:
My name is Margarita.  I sell clothes, cosmetics, beauty accessories, school equipment and other things. I have been in business for four years and the demand is increasing.  For that reason, I need to increase the supply of merchandize for my business. I know if I do this, my income will increase and I'll be able to a better level of life to my family.
 

Translation of the following: 

Mi nombre es Margarita, me dedico a la venta de ropa, cosmeticos, accesorios de belleza para la mujer, utiles escolares y otros. Tengo cuatro años de tener este negocio y la demanda esta incrementando, por lo que necesito abastecer mi negocio con nueva mercaderia. Se que haciendo esto mis ingresos mejoraran y podre ofrecer un mejor nivel de vida a mi famila.

loans.use: Compra de ropa para dama, caballero y niño, cosmeticos, bolsos, accesorios de belleza.

payments.comment: Gracias a la ayuda que me brindaron pude surtir mi inventario y mejorar mis ingresos, ahora necesito invertir capital fresco y renovar para mejorar mis ventas.

loans.name: Francis Dinorah

texts.en:
My name is Dinorah and my store is well known in the city of Danli.  For 9 years, I have been located in a high traffic boulevard.  Because I manage the store and and my kids help me on the weekend, we are able to have a good income which helps sustain our family.

Translated from the below:

Me llamo Dinorah y mi tienda es bastante conocida en la ciudad de Danli, tengo 9 años de tenerla ubicada en uno de los boulevares mas transitados. Lo administro personalmente, mis hijos me ayudan los fines de semana, lo que nos ha permitido tener buenos ingresos que nos ayudan con el sustento de nuestra familia.

loans.use: Compra de ropa Jeans, blusas, camisas, pantalones y variedad para niño.

payments.comment: En este verano las personas buscan variedad de ropa por lo que pude vender mas y pagar mi deuda antes del tiempo, pero si necesito volver a comprar mas ropa para surtir con ropa de verano. Gracias por ayuda.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is the group secretary Karura Mwangaza Women Group. She is married with three children; she is an active member and the secretary of her church.

Mary grows and sells cabbages, Kales and onions to nearby schools and hotels in Wangige-Kiambu. Apart from that, Mary rears dairy cows and sells milk to a local Dairy cooperative society and hotels.

loans.use: Mary would like to buy Onions and cabbages from other farmers because she has won a tender to supply these items to Kanunga High School.

loans.name: Ann

texts.en: Ann is married with two children, after finishing secondary level of education, she was unable to continue to college due to lack of fees. Ann joined WEEC in 2004 and started her small business of selling children’s wear in Karura and Wangige Markets. Last year, she started selling belts and chains. She conducts her business door to door, in meeting places and in market places.

loans.use: She wants to boost her business by buying a bale of mixed children wear.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary attended secondary education and this enables her to get developmental information for her social group. She is married and the couple is blessed with two children.

Mary started her business of selling fruits at Highridge in Nairobi and City Market 13 years ago. She received her first loan of $200 in 2004 and paid it very well. She has been saving with her social group and this has helped her to pay school fees for her child. In August, it is a harvesting period and therefore produce will be relatively cheap. She will earn more if she sells in September.

loans.use: Mary intends to stock maize and buy more fruits as the number of customers increase.

loans.name: Sarahi

texts.en:
I work selling clothes for men, women, children and babies. My business is located on one of the main roads in the city, very close to the transportation centers. At this moment in time, my business is in high demand because of my clothing prices, this helps me to sustain my family. This year, my oldest child will enter High School and I need to continue working to support him in this. I know that my earnings will increase with the investments that I will make.

Loan Use: Buying clothing for babies and children, shirts, socks, blouses, skirts

Me dedico a la venta de ropa para niño, dama y caballero y bebes, mi negocio esta ubicado en una de las principales calles de la ciudad a pocos metros de una de las terminales de transportes. Actualmente mi negocio esta teniendo bastante demanda por los precios en ropa, esto me ayuda a mejorar las oportunidades para tener bien a mi familia. Este año mi hijo mayor sale de secundaria y necesito seguirlo apoyando en su carrera. Se que los ingresos mejoraran con la inversion que hare.

loans.use: Compra de ropa de bebe, niño, camisas, calcetines, blusas, faldas.

payments.comment: Mi deuda la pude pagar antes de tiempo ya que en algunos meses me fue mejor, ahora quiero aprovechar el verano y vender mas varidad.

loans.name: Bridget

texts.en: Bridget is the chairlady of Karura Mwangaza Women Group and a retired primary school teacher. She is married with five children. For many years she has been a chairlady of mothers union and this has increased trust in her from the community around her.Bridget has two dairy cows; they produce between 20-35 litres a day. She sells 30 litres and 5 litres for her home consumption. She supplies milk to a Diary cooperative society and the payments are on time. She is good at book keeping and this assists her in her business as well as helping her group.

loans.use: Bridget wants to construct a permanent structure for her dairy cows.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is an active member of Karura Mwangaza Women Group. She is married and has three beautiful children.

Mary started her business of selling fruits and milk in Nairobi ten years ago.  Her stall is near the gate of one of the biggest housing estates in West lands and these are her major customers.

loans.use: She would like to build a stall because city council allocated small plots to them.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan is the secretary of Karura Mwangaza Women Group a post she has held for the last five years. She is married with one.Susan joined with her fellow members joined WEEC in 2004 when they learnt that it trains women who would like to start there own small businesses. She got her first loan of $100 in march 2004 after attending training. The loan enabled her to start a retail shop in Ndenderu in Kiambu District. She installed a community phone in her shop, sells Celtel and Safari-com airtime cards and the business is doing very well so far.

loans.use: Susan wants to increase the stock of air time cards because the demand is ever increasing.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is among the first members of Karura Mwangaza Women Group. She is married with four children, enterprising and hard working. Two of her children are in secondary while the other two are in primary.

She sells milk to her neighbours and has a stall in Wangige market –Kiambu. She is able to get school fees for her children and for her home upkeep. In addition, she sells fruits and vegetables in the same market.

loans.use: She would like to use dairy feeds to help increase milk production.

loans.name: Olvin Ernesto

texts.en:
I have been working as a barber for 8 years in the community Chichicaste in El Paraiso. I have had much sucess, helped by the fact that there are not many barbers in our community. The earnings I recieve have helped me to build my home and have helped provide food, clothing and resources for schooling and health for my three children.

Loan Use: To buy scissors, razors, powders, mirrors, combs, shampoos

Tengo 8 años de dedicarme a cortar pelo aca en mi comunidad llamada el Chichicaste en El Paraiso, me ha ido muy bien ya que en nuestra comunidad no hay muchos barberos. Los ingresos que percibo por mis trabajos, me han ayudado a poder construir mi casa y ayudar a mis tres hijos con su alimentacion, vestuario, estudios y su salud.

loans.use: Compra de tijeras, rasuradoras, talcos, espejos, peines, shampoo.

loans.name: Maria Eulalia

texts.en:
Everyone knows me as dona Maria, I have had my business, located in the community of Chichicaste, for two years. Aside from selling second hand clothing, I also sell bananas and plantains. I am a widow, upon my husband's death, I had to begin working in order to support the needs of my family. I have two children who help me, but I always like to be independent and to work in order to save and to finish building my house.

Loan Use: Buying bundles of second hand clothing

Todos me conocen como doña Maria, tengo 2 años de tener mi negocios ubicado en la comunidad del Chichicaste, aparte de vender ropa clasificada de segunda, vendo bananos y platanos. Soy viuda al morir mi esposo tuve que comenzar a trabajar y suplir las necesidades de mi familia. Tengo dos hijos que me apoyan pero siempre me gusta ser independiente y trabajar para ahorrar y terminar de construir mi casa.

loans.use: Compra de fardos de ropa clasificada.

loans.name: Marcia Reynalda

texts.en:
My name is doña Marcia and I have a store in which I sell plantains, corn and bananas. I have been working here for six years, my sales have grown and I have been able to help my husband with the family expenses. I am very happy because one of my children has finished High School and will soon be starting his career, because of which, we need more products in order to increase our earnings a little more.

Loan Use: buying bananas. 

Me llaman doña Marcia, tengo una bodega en la que vendo platanos, maiz y bananos. Tengo siete años de tener mi negocios el que ha crecido y me ha ayudado apoyar a mi esposo con los gastos de la familia, me siento muy contenta porque uno de mis hijos ya culmino su secundaria y pronto comenzara su carrera, por lo que necesitamos tener mas producto para mejorar un poco mas los ingresos.

loans.use: Compra de bananos.

loans.name: Marisela Suyapa

texts.en:
I work as a baker, making artesan rolls called rosquillas,  which is a traditional bread in this region of the country. I have been working as a baker for three years, and I have a loyal clientel. My husband is a small farmer and we have to increase our earnings, because our children are of school age and we have to help support them in their studies and provide basic home necessities.

Loan Use: Buying corn, butter, cheese 

Me dedico a la fabricacion artesanal de rosquillas, es un pan tradicional en esta zona del pais, tengo tres años de dedicarme a esta actividad por lo que ya tengo alguna clientela fija. Mi esposo es un pequeño agricultor y tenemos la necesidad de mejorar nuestros ingresos, ya que mis hijos estan en edad escolar y necesitamos apoyarlos en sus estudios y suplir las necesidades basicas del hogar.

loans.use: Compra de maiz, manteca, queso.

loans.name: Martha Lilian

texts.en:
I have a grocery store in which I sell products for daily use like rice, bread, milk, eggs, coffee and other items. It is located en the Montañita, a community in which there are not many businesses and the demand is strong. I need the financing to increase my inventory and to increase sales, so that I can help and support my family more.

Loan Use: milk, bread, eggs, cheese, butter, drinks, over the counter drugs

Tengo una pulperia en la que vendo productos de consumo popular como arroz, pan, leche, huevos, cafe y otros. Esta ubicada en la Montañita una comunidad en la que no hay muchos negocios y la demanda es grande, el financiamiento lo necesito para incrementar mi inventario y mejorar las ventas, para poder ayudar y apoyar mas a mi familia.

loans.use: Compra de leche, pan, huevos, queso, mantequilla, refrescos, medicamentos de uso comun.

loans.name: Tomas

texts.en:
I work in the field of pharmaceuticals, that is, pain relievers, anti-parasite medications, toothpaste, toothbrushes, hairpins, threads, needles, buttons and more. This business took many years to create. One needs to visit grocery stores and markets of the community as well as other neighborhoods. I am saving money in order to build my house and to give to my family security.

Loan Use: Buying medicines and miscellaneous products 

Me dedico a la venta de medicamentos de consumo popular, es decir analgesicos, desparacitantes, pastas dentales, cepillos de dientes, ganchos de pelo, hilos, agujas, botones y otros. Esta actividad la realizo desde hace muchos años. Visitas pulperias, mercaditos, de mi comunidades y otras vecinas. Estoy ahorrando para poder construir mi casa, y derle a mi familia la seguridad necesaria.

loans.use: Compra de medicinas de consumo popular y variedades.

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
My work is selling clothes and cosmetics in a store located on one of the boulevards of the city Danli. I have working in sales for seven years. Thanks to the earnings I recieve, I have been able to help my husband with the family expenses and to give my children the opportunity to continue in their studies. 

Loan Use: Buying women's cosmetics and clothing for men, women and children.

Me dedico a la venta de ropa y cosmeticos en un puesto ubicado en uno de los boulevares de la ciudad de Danli, tengo siete años de dedicarme a esta actividad. Gracias a los ingresos que tengo por las ventas he podido apoyar a mi esposo con los gastos familiares y darle a mis hijos la oportunidad de continuar estudiando.

loans.use: Compra de cosmeticos para dama y ropa para caballeros, bebes y niños.

loans.name: Alba Alicia

texts.en:
My name is Alba, I am a single mother with 2 children. I have been working as a clothing seller for 6 years and I have a permanent stall in the plaza Danli. My business is the only source of income to support my family. Right now, I need to stock my store because the fair is coming to my city and my sales will increase. 

Loan Use: Buying skirts, dresses, shoes, underwear, socks, shirts, pants and fabrics

Mi nombre es Alba, soy madre soltera con 2 hijos, desde hace 6 años me dedico a la venta ambulante de ropa y tengo un puesto permanente en la plaza de Danli, mi negocio es la unica fuente de ingreso para el sosten de mi familia. En este momento necesito surtir mi negocio ya que viene la feria en mi ciudad y las ventas mejoran.

loans.use: Compra de faldas, vestidos, zapatos, ropa interior, calcetines, blusas, pantalones y telas.

loans.name: Sithol

texts.en:
C. Sithol is married and lives with wife and three young children in a new village in Phnom Penh suburbs. He is a moto-taxi driver but is also sometimes employed as a constructor by the families in the neighborhood. He can make around 15,000 Riel daily profit.

 

C. Sithol has a plan to improve his family standards of living. He wants to sell his old motorbike for around $120 and purchase a new one that can pull a cart and which is worth $300. With his cart, C. Sithol will transport soil for people willing to fill their land. He expects to earn around 15,000 from this business.

 

C. Sithol is also building a new house for his family. He just dismantled the old one, which was made of wood, and will use the remaining $340 to buy materials. The house will have one single big room but they did not yet think about which color they want the walls to be painted.

loans.use: Building a new house and buying a new motorbike

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Sarem

texts.en:
N. Sarem has been widowed for 10 years already. She is living with her three children and running a small grocery shop in front of her house. She sells for around 50,000 Riel everyday, out of which she earns a 15,000 Riel daily profit. Her two grown daughters are also contributing to the household’s income with her factory workers salaries.

 

N. Sarem applied for a first loan of $700 because her neighbor told her about CREDIT. She would like to open a new business, selling second-hand clothes in the nearby market. She needs running capital to start the business, to purchase the clothes and to pay the daily market fee, which is 3,000 Riel. She expects 37,000 Riel daily profit ($9.25).

 

After this cycle, N. Sarem would like to invest more in her business. She would like to purchase a selling spot in the market, so that she no longer needs to rent it. The 1.5m*1.5m plot is worth $1000.

loans.use: Opening a second-hand clothing shop in the market

loans.name: Sakhon

texts.en:
S. Sakhon is a widow and lives with her 4 sons in Tah Kmao, Kandal Province, about 10km from Phnom Penh. She supports her family in selling vegetables on the market near to hear house. She can earn around 30,000 Riel ($7.5) per day. She has been doing this business successfully for 5 years already and invested her first CREDIT loan to expand it. She never repaid one single installment late.

 

Now that three of her sons are employed, S. Sakhon is more secure and would like to improve her house. She requested $800 as a second loan and plans to spend $500 for housing improvements and $300 to invest in her business. She will purchase wood and zinc and will hire one or two skilled workers; perhaps will the neighbors come to help.

 

S. Sakhon is confident for her future, she is satisfied with her business and is not going to change.

loans.use: Repair her house and invest in her business

loans.name: Tov

texts.en:
T. Tov is living in Phnom Penh, near to the railways, with her daughter and grandson. She is earning some money in sewing clothes at home on her own sewing machine. Her profit is around 12,000 Riel ($3) daily with one machine but she has another source of income. She has rooms for rent in a nearby building. She rent it to the factory workers and the beer girls working in the city. There are five rooms, each of them is rented for $15 monthly. This breeds an additional $75 to the family income.

T. Tov requested $700 to invest in both of her businesses. The first $300 will be spent for purchasing a new sewing machine and to have the other one repaired. This new machine will be used by her daughter.

T. Tov will use the remaining $400 to have her house with rooms for rent repaired. She perceives it has an important investment for her future.

She is very excited about receiving her loan. “When CREDIT will give out my loan, our income will rise”, she said. With her future loan she would like to develop her sewing business, buy more machines and hire employees.

loans.use: Buying a sewing machine and repairing her house to rent rooms

loans.name: Eulalia

texts.en: Eulalia’s business is banana chips. She sells them at the market and also supplies it to some Supermarkets in the town area of Apia. With her current loan, she was given the amount of $775 and has used it to buy ingredients for her banana chips and maintenance of her kitchen. Eulalia is planning to extend her business with her next loan, to delivering of her chips to shops and schools in both urban and rural areas.

loans.use: Buying Ingredients/Maintenance

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Tiki

texts.en:
Tiki is married with three children aged 2, 6 and 12. She runs a small corner store which is located in the suburb of Tufiopa in the capital of Apia. Since joining the SPBD program she has had three loans. With the first loan of $300 she purchased stock for the store. The profit from this allowed her to buy a ceiling fan. With her second loan of $500 she again purchased stock for her store and used the profit to buy a new kitchen sink and extend her store. With her current loan of $775 she is renovating her bathroom. 

For two years Tiki was the secretary of the Tufiopa center and played a key role in organizing the center and enforcing the group and center guarantees. The meeting is held in her house which is also the location of the store. She is currently renovating the area where the meeting is held to make it into a small café – utilizing the ceiling fan, sink and new bathroom facilities. She has also used this part of the house (adjacent to the shop) to run a small day care center.

loans.use: Purchase stock and home improvement

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Taloa

texts.en: Taloa owns a two acre land in her village where her plantation is at.  With her $250 loan, she has used it to buy working tools for her business and also school fees for her children. With her taro plantation, she takes them to the market three times a week and also sells them at Salani Surf Resort next to her village. She plans to improve her business by purchasing another acre beside her plantation to start another business which is cattle farming.

loans.use: Business improvement/school fees

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Ipu

texts.en: Ipu is a married woman with 10 children. She runs a family business which cuts lawns in Samoa. She has had two loans from SPBD and is now seeking a third. With her first $100 loan she was able to renovate a shed which houses the business. This enabled the business to be moved from her house. With her second loan she was able to buy a new weed eater and she wishes to use her third loan for the same. At the moment the business owns 4 second hand weed eaters. At the moment the business has five regular customers whose lawns are mown once a fortnight. The business also does many non regular jobs and is looking to expand.

loans.use: Purchase a “weed eater”

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Iaeli

texts.en: Iaeli F.’s business is a small shop. With her first loan of $120, she started her small shop with selling sugar, rice, salt, flour and onions, now with her 4th loan of $750, she has extended her business, selling different variety of goods, such as tin meats, snacks, frozen foods, beverages and also clothes. Iaeli’s business has turned out to be one of the successful businesses within the SBPD’s program. She also won the best saver for 2005’s Savings Program.

loans.use: Restock shop

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Astou

texts.en:
This loan request has been submitted by the thirty members of the women’s tontine Soppanté Takku Liggéey, represented by Astou T..  Based in the traditional fishing village of Yoff, the group is well known locally for their manufacture of quality juices, syrups and marmalades from such typical African produce as bissap (dried and preserved flowers of the bissap plant), lemon, “monkey bread” (pulp from the seed pods of the baobab tree), made (a round tree fruit whose sour seeds are used in cooking), and tamarind.  The women of Soppanté Takku Liggéey also engage in other activities such as fruit and vegetable gardening, production of traditional hand-dyed cloth, and the provision of literacy training in the local language, Wolof.  The $900 loan requested by the group will be used to expand and commercialize their juice- and marmalade-production business, including the purchase of ingredients such as bissap flowers, tamarind, sugar, “monkey bread”, lemon, ginger, and made fruits; equipment including pots, a puree mill, and a supply of water and cooking gas; and transportation of the finished products to market.  Repayments will be made on a monthly basis throughout the term of the loan, which has been agreed at twelve months from the date funds are received by the group.

 

 

Background

Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group.  Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, known as tontines.  Commonly organized by groups of twenty to thirty housewives who live in the same village, the tontines provide poor women throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities.  Repayment rates within these associations are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members.  However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income.  This has prevented the traditional tontines from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities.  Senegal Ecovillage Microfinance (SEM) works with our partner organization CRESP to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance.

loans.use: Juice and Marmalade Production

loans.name: Georgette

texts.en:
This loan request has been submitted by the women’s tontine Kaalee Jiwent, represented by Georgette M..  Founded over ten years ago in the riverside village of Oussouye in southern Senegal, the Kaalee Jiwent group is especially well known for its production of artisanal pottery, as well as other traditional local activities such as pig-raising and the sale of garden fruits and vegetables.  The $1000 loan requested by the group will be used for the following commercial activities: 
  • Pig-raising: loan funds will be used to buy young pigs, which will be raised by the group members themselves; the members will also need to purchase feed such as hay and tourte (the pulp left over after peanuts are pressed for oil) and other feeds necessary to fatten the pigs so that they can be sold in the town market, where the demand for pork exceeds the supply.
  • Artisanal pottery production and sale: funds will be used for transport by donkey of the larger quantities of clay, sand and firewood needed for commercial pottery production; and for transportation of the finished pots, jars, etc. to markets in nearby cities, where they are in great demand by both locals and tourists.

Background

loans.use: Pig Raising, Artisanal Pottery

loans.name: Norma

texts.en: Norma P. who was born in Chimborazo, Ecuador has lived in Guayaquil for 15 years. This 37 year-old entrepreneur is married and has two children. In her shop (her home as well) she sells some of the most delicious bread and sweets Guayaquil has to offer. Norma has run her bakery for 12 years after having learned the trade from her parents. Now that she is married, she runs her independent business from 5:00 am until 8:00 pm. Like similar Mifex borrowers, Ms. P. receives help from her husband when he is not driving his taxi, but she is responsible for the day-to-day activities of running the bakery. She needs this loan so that she can buy essential ingredients for bread-making and a display case to show off her tasty treats. Norma wants lenders to know that is very responsible and hard-working.

loans.use: Bakery supplies and display case

payments.comment: Se procedio a cancelar el credito desfaces en la documentacion saendeudada.

loans.name: Wilfredo

texts.en: Wilfredo A., who was born in Loja, Ecuador has lived in Guayaquil for 10 years. This 40 year-old small business owner is divorced and has 3 children. He sells household items and ice cream and has been doing so ever since he arrived in Guayaquil. Wilfredo’s venture is run out of the home, and his most frequent customers live in the neighborhood. This hardworking entrepreneur opens his shop at 6:00 am and closes at 9:00 pm. He needs a $950 loan so that he can purchase more goods and diversify his product supply. Don Wilfredo is trying very hard to move forward and work himself out of poverty, giving his children opportunities that he never had.

loans.use: Purchase goods for small market

loans.name: Luz

texts.en: Luz G., born in Bahia de Caráquez, has lived in Guayaquil, Ecuador for 10 years now with her parents and brothers. She is 44 years old and has two children. Luz’s business sells household items and candy, and it is run out of her house. She has been in business for 15 years and works from 6:00 am until 8:00 pm. When her husband is not driving his taxi, he helps out with the business. Luz would like an $800 loan so that she can buy a display case and buy products that her clientele requests. Ms. G. and her husband demonstrated that they can run an efficient business and that they have a proper understanding of financial management. Luz reports that she does not want to be forced to borrow from a loan shark because they charge outrageous interest rates and impede the progress of her business.

loans.use: Purchase inventory for household item market

payments.comment: Se pidio la cancelacion del credito, la razon fue que la documentacion contenia inconcistencias en la informacion entregada.

loans.name: Ángel

texts.en: Don Angel is a 29 year-old native of Valencia, Ecuador who, along with his wife, owns a house and cares for his three children. His business is selling platanos and yucca, and he has been honing his skills for 5 years. Plátano y Yuca Don Ángel is located in the Municipal de Bastión Popular, a large marketplace where entrepreneurs sell their goods. He works from 4:00 am until 12:00, but he could not operate without the help of his right-hand woman – his wife. They both alternate going out to other provinces to stock up on the finest yucca and platanos. They are requesting a loan of $1030 so they can purchase food in cash and receive a discount. Ultimately, this capital will enable them to serve a wider market than just the frequent customers of the Bastion Popular. Our evaluation of their business is that it is sustainable because Don Angel and his wife are hard-working, proven, and responsible. With the help of this Mifex loan these entrepreneurs hope to make improvements on their house and provide a better future for their children.

loans.use: Purchase inventory for vegetable market

loans.name: Emily

texts.en: Emily is an active member of Tabby Mothers Women group. She is married and is blessed with two children. She works as a school Matron at Muguru High School. She started to operate a kiosk near the school to supplement her monthly salary as a school matron. The small kiosk has helped her in the day to day requirements of her home while her monthly salary is saved for other developments. The business is on the right track and at least it brings in an average of $120 per month. There is an opportunity for expansion because the number of students is increasing and therefore, the stock should much with the growth of the school. With this trend, she will have no difficulty in educating her children and maintaining good standard of living.

loans.use: She would like to stock her kiosk with soap, sugar, bread, doughnuts and yellow banana.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is married and fortunately all her children are out of school. Susan is a good member in the group and actively brings in new ideas that promotes its growth.

Susan has been a farmer for over 20 years. She grows and sells maize, beans, coffee, and milk from her own cow. Selling of maize, beans and coffee is seasonal; thus, most of her income comes from selling milk because it’s sold daily. Susan earns $42 and $28 from sale of milk and other produce per month respectively. Though the earnings are little, she is able to cater for her needs; she is not worried about food at home, she gets it from her own farm. This will increase her income and supplement the little she is getting from the farm. She is optimistic the business will succeed because of its uniqueness within the area.

loans.use: She wants to buy plates to be hired by funeral ceremonies, weddings and other functions in the area.

loans.name: Manuela

texts.en: Manuela G. who was born in Chimborazo, Ecuador is a 45 year-old married entrepreneur. She runs a small vegetable market that she and her husband rent in the busy district. Manuela has been the owner of this particular business for 4 years, but she thanks her parents and husband for teaching her how to run such a business. Their advice about where to find the best products for the lowest price, as well as how to display her vegetables has been valuable. Ms. G. works from 6 a.m. until 5 p.m. She is asking for a $465 loan to purchase more vegetables in cash, allowing her to get wholesale discounts. Manuela wants lenders to know that she is a hard-working and industrious woman who wants her business to succeed.

loans.use: Purchase vegetables in cash from local suppliers

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria U. is a 38 year-old woman from Azoguez, Ecuador with three children. She is married and owns her home. Ms. U. owns a small business that specializes in vegetables and fruits. Her shop is located near her house in the Mercado Municipal (Enrique Grau), and the normal customers are neighborhood locals. Victoria has 25 years of experience selling at her current market, which was passed down to her from her parents. She feels a duty to work extremely hard because this is the only business she has ever known, and her parents spent many years building it up. Victoria’s husband is her right-hand man, partner, and motivator. They work together in the market from 6 a.m. until 1 p.m., and she is asking for a $575 loan to buy more vegetables and a new scale for weighing items. Together Victoria and her husband are an entrepreneurial pair full of perseverance.

loans.use: Purchase more vegetables from wholesalers as well as a new scale

payments.comment: Procede a cancelar deuda por tener familiar enferno y no hay quien atienda el negocio. espera superar este iconveniente pronto.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is an active member of Mercury Mothers where she is a secretary. She is married and has four children. Her major business activity is growing and selling of maize, beans, avocados and on a small scale coffee. In addition, she has a dairy cow and this gives her some extra income. The monthly sales from avocados and milk total $88, whereas coffee sales of about $70 come in every month. The vegetables also contribute to her monthly income but minimally because they are mainly for home consumption. 

Esther has been spending so much money on paraffin to light her home and electricity is so expensive and not reliable in her area.

loans.use: Esther wants to buy a solar panel for to be used at her home.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria P. is a native of Guayaquil, Ecuador, and she runs a small shop that sells food items and drinks. This mother of two children, one of whom still depends on her financially, is a homeowner. Located in her house, “Tienda Jenny” is a bustling little store that sells to customers in the neighborhood in need of candy, juices, and soda. With 20 years of experience managing her shop, Gloria is a local favorite. Many of the young children that attend the school across the street come to her store after class. Working from 6 a.m. until 8 p.m. Gloria is a hard-working, entrepreneurial woman. She is asking for a $575 loan to buy more products for her store and diversify the supply.

loans.use: Gloria needs this loan to diversify her product inventory and purchase items which school children request

payments.comment: Solicito cancelacion total operacion datos de solicitud no contemplan otros creditos adeudados.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria Ortiz who is a 49 year-old originally from Cañar, Ecuador has two children and runs a small music store. Ms. Ortiz lost her husband a few years ago and is completely in charge of managing the business and supporting her young ones. Her store which is in the Municipal Enrique Grau has 25 years of experience and sells CDs and Ecuadorian music recordings to members of the community. Every day from 6 a.m. until 6 p.m. Maria takes care of the store. She is asking for a $355 loan to be able to buy different products in cash, so that she can get a discount from her supplier. She wants lenders to know that she is industrious and emprendedora – or entrepreneurial.

loans.use: Maria needs this $355 loan to purchase media from her suppliers in bulk so that she can get discounts

payments.comment: Se le solicito cancelacion del credito datos de endeudamiento no son igual a los de la solicitud.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria P. was born in Guayaquil, Ecuador and is 39 years old. She divorced but later remarried a very supportive husband, with whom she had two children. Together they are homeowners. Gloria runs a thriving construction supply store – look out Home Depot! Her shop is located in the large market called Municipal Cinco Esquina. Ms. P. has 15 years of experience selling home construction materials, but she has only been selling in the Municipal for the last two years. Her husband helps her purchase the wholesale goods from large manufacturers. Without him Gloria could not run her business. From 6 a.m. until 5 p.m. these two entrepreneurs work together to sell materials to locals who are constantly making home improvements. She is asking for $1,200 to buy a variety of quality products that her clients ask for. Like most other Mifex borrowers, Gloria will be able to buy a higher quantity of goods if she can purchase supplies in cash because of the discounts. She wants to continue growing her business and is hoping that the kind lenders who see her profile will “invest” in her future.

loans.use: Gloria is asking for $1200 so that she can start carrying quality home supply products and tools for refining the finished products

loans.name: Gladwel

texts.en:
Gladwel is a hard working lady and a good member of Mercury Women Group. She is married and has three children who go to school. Two are in primary while others are in secondary school.

Her major source of income comes from growing and selling maize, beans, arrow roots, potatoes and vegetables. She also sells milk from her dairy cow. Presently, the market for milk has improved due to the revival of dairy cooperative societies in Kenya. Therefore, buying another cow would be a good investment because of ready market for milk. This will provide daily income for along time. The proceeds from the sale of vegetables and other produce will contribute greatly to the well being of her family and other developments.

loans.use: She wants to buy another cow so as to increase milk production.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en: Nancy is married with three children. She is a member of Mercury Women Group which helps women in mobilization of savings and provides small credit to members. From her savings, she has been able to buy a dairy cow and still continues to save with the group. She sells and grows maize, beans, and vegetables; also, she has a dairy cow which gives her milk for sale and home consumption.  In addition, she has two rental rooms in Gatangara-Kangema. She gets $28 from the two rooms and $42 from sell of milk per month. She is working very hard to reach a turn over of at least $100 per month. With this she will have the capacity to save small amounts to help her in supporting her family.

loans.use: She wants to buy hybrid seeds and animal feeds to increase productivity.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is an active member of Mercury Women Group. She has been a member of this group for the last four years. She is married and has five children, one in college and others in secondary school. She grows and sells tea Leaves and coffee. She earns $57 from the sale of tealeaves and $23 per month. She has a dairy cow, which gives her milk for sale and home consumption. She gets between10 to 15 litres of milk every day; this gives her on average $3.5 a day. With this income, she will not be in a position of sending her children to college and this is why she is striving to increase her milk production and consequently her income.

loans.use: She would like to improve on cattle feeds to increase milk production.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is married and has two beautiful girls. She joined Mercury Women Group two years ago and the group has helped her in improving her business skills and instilling in her a culture of saving. Presently, she has accumulated savings of $100 and continues to save because she wants to buy a dairy cow when her savings reach $400. She grows and sells maize, beans, and bananas. She has a dairy cow which gives her milk for home consumption and some for sale. Her monthly income from her business is about $50, this is not enough to sustain the family and thus additiional funding will help greatly.

loans.use: She would like to improve her farmland by buying fertilizers so as to increase output per acre.

loans.name: Loyce

texts.en: Loyce is a hard workingwoman who has been working with Mercury Women Group since 2004. Joining this group helped her greatly because she learnt the use of savings and starting an income-generating project. Through her small savings, she bought a dairy cow at the beginning of this year in February. She gets 15 litres of milk every day and changing the type of feeds can increase milk. She hopes to increase milk production to at least 20 litres of milk; this will give her $5 per day. She will go an extra mile in improving her standard of living.

loans.use: To increase milk production, she wants to  buy improved dairy feeds.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah has been a good member of Mercury Mothers Women Group since 2002. She is hard working and utilizes every opportunity to her disposal. She has managed to educate her children and bought 2 dairy cows. She grows and sells vegetables, beans and maize. Her sales per month total $100 but in a dry season it falls down because of limited water to irrigate the crops. This is why she wants to buy a water tank in order to store enough water. After buying a water tank, her income inflow will remain positive and growth will be realized.

loans.use: She wants to buy a water tank to store water for irrigation in a dry season.

loans.name: Ann

texts.en: Ann is married with two children. Her source of income is from her secretarial job and selling of milk. She grows vegetables, maize, and beans for home consumption. Her monthly income is about $57; she is striving to save at least $40 a month. This cash inflow is not enough but adequate to improve her business and push her to save more. This will help her to buy another cow.

loans.use: She wants to buy a dairy goat to produce milk for her family because of its nutritional value.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane has been a member of Mercury Women Group since 2002. She is married and has six children, three are already married and the rest in college. Currently, her major source of income comes from selling milk and vegetables in Kangema town. As she sold her milk in town, she was approached by a number of people who wanted local chicken. She gave it a try and the first batch sold out very quickly.  She is receiving many orders and this why she wants to put in more funds. The local chicken in the villages cost $1.4; while in town she sells at $3. This is good enough to push her to better living conditions and solving the challenge of paying school.

loans.use: She wants to buy 70 local chicks to be reared for three months and then be sold.

loans.name: Daouda

texts.en:
This microbusiness is a partnership between a master tailor, an artist and a seamstress skilled in traditional embroidery.  They currently run a small village workshop that produces quality artisanal fabrics, ready-to-wear and custom-tailored clothing, and hand-decorated T-shirts for a clientele base that extends as far away as the capital city, Dakar.  However, they would like to boost profitability by making some investments that would allow them to expand their business and more successfully target the local tourist market.  They have requested a loan to finance the following activities:

  • Modernizing the tailor’s workshop: repairing the building; purchasing a sewing machine, a worktable and chairs

  • Creating a workspace and purchasing canvases and other supplies that the artist needs to produce his paintings

  • Starting a small eatery and cold drink bar to be combined with the tailor/artist workshop: this will be profitable in its own right because of the large numbers of tourists that visit the area.  It will also provide an opportunity to permanently showcase the paintings and will attract customers to the tailor’s workshop. 

The team emphasized in their loan application that this enterprise is not only a sound business investment, but will also help to promote the value of their local artistic traditions and introduce young people in the village to artistic production techniques.

 

Background

Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group.  Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, which provide the rural poor throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities.  Repayment rates within these groups are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members.  However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income.  This has prevented the traditional associations from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities.  Senegal Ecovillage Microfinance (SEM) works with our partner organization CRESP to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance.

loans.use: Renovation of village artistic workshop and addition of a restaurant bar to target tourist market

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Diegane

texts.en:
This is a group loan request submitted by the twenty-one members of the village credit and savings association Aspovrece, represented by Diegane D..  The group will use the loan to open a small general store and hardware shop, which requires the following investments:

  • Shop building rental and electricity
  • Wholesale purchase of food items, household supplies and hardware for retail

This enterprise will not only generate a profit for the Aspovrece group, but will also make it more convenient and affordable for the local villagers to purchase everyday household items.

loans.use: General store/hardware shop

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.en:
This is a group loan request submitted by the five members of the Nanoor association, represented by Mamadou F..  The Nanoor group hails from the coastal fishing village of Palmerin, where the surrounding grasslands are ideal for livestock grazing.  Mamadou and his associates plan to take advantage of this natural resource by purchasing a quantity of young goats to raise.  Goat meat is always in demand in Palmarin and the surrounding areas, where it is commonly stewed in a spicy sauce and served over millet.  The Nanoor group considers their enterprise a sound investment, as a young goat purchased for about $30 will easily fetch $50 after four months of fattening on Palmerin’s good pastureland.  They have committed to begin repaying their loan in monthly instalments four months after receipt of funding, giving them enough time to purchase, raise, fatten and begin to sell the goats.

 

Background

Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group.  Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, which provide the rural poor throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities.  Repayment rates within these groups are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members.  However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income.  This has prevented the traditional associations from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities.  Senegal Ecovillage Microfinance (SEM) works with our partner organization CRESP to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance.

loans.use: Purchase of young goats

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Aïssatou

texts.en:
This is a group loan request submitted by the twenty-five members of the women’s tontine Waag Baax, represented by Aïssatou N..  The Waag Baax group has long managed a communal microenterprise specializing in the crafting and sale of the batiks and other vibrant hand-dyed cloth for which Senegal is well known.  Aïssatou and her associates have a loyal clientele base as well as considerable money management and sales experience.  The loan will be used for the expansion of their dying business, including investments in the purchase of materials (cloth, dyes), equipments (larger pots and vats, gloves) and transportation of the finished goods to market. 

Background

Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group.  Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, known as tontines.  Commonly organized by groups of twenty to thirty housewives who live in the same village, the tontines provide poor women throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities.  Repayment rates within these associations are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members.  However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income.  This has prevented the traditional tontines from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities.  Senegal Ecovillage Microfinance (SEM) works with our partner organization CRESP to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance.

loans.use: Expansion of cloth-dying business

loans.name: Célestine

texts.en:
This is a group loan request submitted by the ten members of the women’s tontine Takusaan de Ayidjidjo, represented by Célestine D..  Here is a translation of their microenterprise proposal:  “This is a project of small-scale trade in local products of the département of Oussouye (lemon juice, palm oil and dried fish).  These products, which are very abundant within the département, will be purchased and resold in areas where they are in short supply – in other words, the exchange of products between regions.  These products, which are in high demand and very nutritious, have motivated us to present this proposal for financing, after a study of the market and previous attempts at these activities with very limited financial resources.  The objective of the loan is to:
  • Reduce the problem of rural migration
  • Create employment for women
  • Help to improve and diversify the local diet and to ensure self-sufficiency in food

  The activities of the enterprise are: the sale of local products (lemon juice, palm oil, dried fish).  These products will be purchased in Oussouye and resold in areas where they are lacking such as Kolda, Tamba, Kaolack, and Dakar; by ship or by highway.  We are sure of being able to repay the entire loan without any difficulty and thereby remaining eligible for additional financing.  

To start the business:

Lemon juice:    350 F * 150 l *3 =      157500 F

Palm oil:           1000 F * 120 l * 2 =   240000 F

Dried fish:        500 F * 150 kg * 2 =  150000 F

Forestry taxes                                     50000 F

Total:                                                  700000 F”  

Background

Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group.  Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, known as tontines.  Commonly organized by groups of twenty to thirty housewives who live in the same village, the tontines provide poor women throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities.  Repayment rates within these associations are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members.  However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income.  This has prevented the traditional tontines from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities.  Senegal Ecovillage Microfinance (SEM) works with our partner organization CRESP to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance.

loans.use: Purchase of local products - lemon juice, palm oil and dried fish - and transport to other regional markets for resale

loans.name: Fagaye

texts.en:
This is a group loan request submitted by the ten members of the women’s tontine Femmes Couturières, represented by Fagaye D..  Located in the traditional fishing village of Yoff, the Femmes Couturières group currently manages a small tailoring business in which each member specializes in a part of the clothing production process.  They already have a sewing machine and basic sewing supplies such as scissors and needles, but they would like to make their business more attractive to clients by stocking up on a greater variety of fabrics.  The loan will be used to purchase the necessary fabrics as well as accessories such as buttons, epaulettes and embroidery thread.

loans.use: Purchase of cloth and sewing supplies

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
This is a group loan request submitted by the twenty-four members of the women’s tontine Balindite, represented by Jacqueline D..  Founded over ten years ago in the southern village of Mlomp, the Balindite group engages in a variety of commercial activities, including: 

  • Transportation and sale of produce grown in their household gardens as far away as the bordering countries of Gambia and Guinea-Bissau 
  • Traditional local crafts: soap making, batik cloth-dying, and mat and basket weaving 

The loan requested by the group would be invested in materials and supplies for their gardening and craft activities, and the transportation of the finished goods to market.

loans.use: Purchase of materials for gardening and craft production, transportation to market

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Elisabeth

texts.en:
This is a group loan request submitted by the women’s tontine Tessito, represented by Elisabeth S..  Hailing from the village of Oussouye on the banks of the Casamance River in the south of Senegal, the Tessito group’s principal business activity is the cultivation of garden produce for the local market.  They would like to use their loan to expand their gardening activities by purchasing seeds, fertilizer, and basic equipment such as watering cans, rakes, and hoes.

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and gardening equipment

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
This is a group loan request submitted by the women’s tontine Taku Ligueye, represented by Lilian S..  The funds would finance the expansion of the women’s produce marketing business, including:

  • The purchase of seeds, fertilizer and basic gardening supplies such as rakes and watering cans
  • Transportation of the harvested fruits and vegetables to the local Oussouye village market. 

According to Lilian and her associates, produce marketing is especially profitable in Oussouye because of the strong local demand for fresh produce and the village's location near a national highway.    

 

Background

 Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group.  Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, known as tontines.  Commonly organized by groups of twenty to thirty housewives who live in the same village, the tontines provide poor women throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities.  Repayment rates within these associations are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members.  However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income.  This has prevented the traditional tontines from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities.  Senegal Ecovillage Microfinance (SEM) works with our partner organization CRESP to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance.

loans.use: Seeds and gardening equipment purchase

loans.name: Ibrahima

texts.en:
This is a group loan to be shared by five entrepreneurs hailing from the island village of Carabane at the mouth of the Casamance river in southern Senegal.  The group is represented by Ibrahima N., who submitted the following business proposal:  

“The activities to be undertaken are: traditional net fishing, which will be done with traditional pirogues (handmade wooden canoes).  We are going to sell the fish not only to the tourist hotels and restaurants, but also to the surrounding villages.  We have already targeted the markets for the sale of our products.  We are going to do our best to sell at prices that are affordable for the local population.  We will also have the option of processing our products (fish and other seafood) into dried fish.  All of these factors will allow us to earn money, to build up our savings and to repay this loan on time – because us islanders, we know how profitable net fishing is because fish is a real necessity here.  

For the budget we need: 

5 pirogues                               *  80000 F      =  400000 F

5 roles of string                        *  7000 F        =  35000 F

5 * 70 net weights                    *  25 F            =  8750 F

5 buckets                                 *  1000 F        =  5000 F

5 oars                                      *  2000 F        =  10000 F

5 nets                                      *  23000 F      =  115000 F

Towing fees for the pirogues   15000 F * 5    =  75000 F

Unforeseen expenses (price increases etc.)      =  16250 F 

Net budget                                                      =  683750 F

Net budget + unforeseen expenses                  =  700000 F”

Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group.  Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, which provide the rural poor throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities.  Repayment rates within these groups are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members.  However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income.  This has prevented the traditional associations from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities.  Senegal Ecovillage Microfinance (SEM) works with our partner organization CRESP to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance.

loans.use: Purchase of fishing canoes

loans.name: Ibrahima

texts.en:
This is a group loan to be shared by four entrepreneurs hailing from the island village of Cachuouane in southern Senegal.  Their representative, Ibrahima T., submitted the following business proposal:  

 

“The group ‘Assoukatene’ is made up of four men who are all traditional fishermen and who have decided to work in collaboration.  The group wishes to purchase nets and rowing pirogues (the handmade wooden canoes of Senegal).  The group will be divided into two teams of two fishermen who will undertake all types of fishing in order to provide the local population with fish, throughout every season of the year.  We will be able to repay the loan without problems in a matter of months after we begin these activities.”  

 

Note from CRESP: The attached photo depicts traditional pirogues and fishermen in the Casamance River, however the individuals in the photo are NOT from the Assoukatene group.  We will update this entry with pictures of Ibrahima and his associates as soon as possible.
