loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is married with 6 children. Three of them are in school; one is in Nairobi University while the last-born is in standard six. Margaret is the vice secretary in her group and an active member of Catholic Women Association, Nairobi Archdiocese.

Back home, she is both the secretary in her local church and at Saint Samuel Small Christian Community. (Jumuiya)

Margaret has dairy cows and grows kales, spinach and carrots in her plot near Kanunga shopping centre. Currently, she has 3 dairy cows, which produce more than 30 litres of milk daily. She sells her milk to Kiamba Dairy Cooperative Society. Residents around the area buy her vegetables. Her business can’t raise $ 300 at once and thus the need for a loan.

loans.use: Margaret would like to pay her daughter’s tuition; she is in second year at Nairobi University.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is married with 6 children. She is now 61 years old. She has been in sagana for more than 6 years. She is an active group member, has borrowed and serviced 6 loans, the latest being $300.

She runs a retail shop in her own premises at Sagana town. She started her shop 6 years ago and she is also a farmer. She grows vegetables, maize and beans both for sale as well as for home use. Her retail business is doing well and manages to make sales of up to $10 per day. She makes profit of about $58 per month and this supports her family. However, the business is not fully stocked because she doesn’t have enough funds. This loan will boost her business because customers tend to buy from well stocked shops.

loans.use: Rebecca will use the loan to stock her shop with the following products sugar, flour, cooking fat & detergents.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is an active group member of Kabuta ladies in action. She has 4 children and fortunately they finished college and three of them are working. She supports her nephew with school fees and she pays $228 every year.

She started her business 9 years ago. Currently she has 2 dairy cows producing 17 litres in the morning & 10litres in the evening. She sells 25 litres per day at $ 29 cents per litre. She also farms horticultural products in her farm. Currently she has planted watermelon & butternuts, which she expects to harvest about 2000kg by end of August. This will give her roughly $200. She sells her fruits to people with groceries and market stall in muranga town as well as sagana market. She employs 3 permanent workers and pays them a total of $77 per month.

loans.use: : She wants to buy pipes, sprinklers 7 fittings, for irrigation purpose. She will plant kales to meet the local demand.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is an active member of Kabuta ladies in action and a hardworking business lady. She is married and with 4 children one in primary and the other in secondary school.

Virginia started her business over 10years ago. She has 3 different businesses namely Jaribu wholesaler & retailers, oceanic bar & restaurant and Coro bar. All her businesses are in Sagana town. Jaribu wholesale/retailers is the business she expects to expand. She makes sales of usd100per day. Her main products are foodstuffs, household items such as soap, salt, rice, wheat flour & detergents. She employs 7 workers in all her businesses and currently they are doing very well.

loans.use: Virginia wants to stock more rice and be able to supply Muranga clients who are more reliable and offer high prices than Sagana.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is an active member of Kabuta ladies in action. Nancy is 32 years old married and has 3 children. Her first loan was USD100 and she paid it very well.

Nancy has a dairy cow, which produces10 litres of milk daily. Currently, the cow is about to give birth and the milk will increase to 20 litres per day. She is also a teacher at Kambwe primary school. She sells her milk to a cooperative society at $28 cents per litre and this will give her $5 per day.

loans.use: Nancy intends to pay school fees for her 2 sons who are in college.

loans.name: Abdrahman

texts.en: Abdurrahman lives in Kongowe area in Dar es Salaam. He is married with three children. He owns a shop selling soft drinks in retail and wholesale. He has another business of selling fruits and vegetables of which his wife is in charge. Soft drinks business has higher turnover in his shop, mainly caused by hot weather of Dar es Salaam. Demand for soft drinks is high. Abdrahman can not meet this demand. He is in need of USD 1000 as a working capital to meet his expectations.

loans.use: WORKING CAPITAL

loans.name: Mlamua

texts.en: Mlamua lives in Mbagala in Dar es Salaam. He is married with three children. He is self employed and owns a small shop near his residence. The shop sells different consumable items. Mainly food items, which have high demand.  The shop provides him with an opportunity to raise his children. He would like to expand his business so that he can meet costs of educating his children. The shop employs himself and his wife. To expand his business he needs  USD 1000

loans.use: WORKING CAPITAL

loans.name: Aminata

texts.en: Aminata is married with three children.She runs a  hair dressing business in a busy area of Kariakoo in Dar es Salaam.She has employed two people in her business. In normal business days,her saloon is usually flocked with customers.She need to add some comfortable sitting chairs to hold these customers on the queue.She also usually in short of hair dressing materials.The equipments used for hair dressing need to be highly sterilized to reduce the risk of HIV transmission and other skin deseases.To effectively run her business she need an additional working capital of USD 750

loans.use: WORKING CAPITAL

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 40 years old married with 3 children. She is an active member of Christian Women Association in her local church. Her contribution to the community is mainly helping the needy people– i.e. the elderly, the orphans and HIV\AIDS victims. Grace and the other members makes visit the needy and give them food, clothing and do the homestead chores that are at times left unattended to. They do bible study with the needy and encourage them using bible teachings.

Grace has a small retail shop which she operates. She works in the shop together with her younger brother who has completed secondary school. She sells retail items like sugar, salt, soap, etc. She also stocks polythene bags and sells mainly to the market vendors who operate from the nearby Kiserian market. Her dream is to operate a small kerosene depot. She would be buying her stock from the kerosene distributors and selling to the local residents. During the market day she will be selling paraffin to the maasai community who come to the market.

loans.use: Grace would like to buy paraffin in drums at wholesale price from the distributors and sell the same at retail price at her retail shop.

loans.name: Jemima

texts.en:
Jemima is 43 years old, married with 4 children of her own. Jemima lives with 2 other grown up children – One boy is in form two. Jemima’s sister in-law passed away and the boy was left under her care. The second boy passed his secondary exams very well. His family could not afford to pay for him tuition to join the University. Jemima decided to sponsor him at University instead of dropping off. She has been taking care of his requirements since then.

Jemima has a charcoal stall in Kiserian. Most of the food Kiosks and the households in the area prefer the use of charcoal than kerosene and firewood because it convenient to use and relatively cheaper. Jemima sells charcoal to the local residents. She sells 25 cans of charcoal per day and makes 10 dollars. Some Medium size hotels and Kiosks purchase the Charcoal in Sacks. At times she can sell up to 5 sacks at 8 dollars per sack. Jemima would wish to take orders from the local community when they are holding festivities – Mostly churches, weddings and funeral festivities. This will satisfy her clients by stocking at least 60 sacks rather than the current 30 sacks.

loans.use: Jemima would like to buy charcoal whole; this can only be done by buying 50 bags and above.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is married with two Children. She lives with her family in kiserian. Their family owns the plot on which they have constructed their house. Veronica is a strong member of the local PCEA church.  Veronica takes care of her niece who is an orphan; she pays for her school fees and other necessities. She promised her that she will look after her until she joins college.

Veronica has one dairy cow that gives her 6 liters of milk per day. She supplies the milk to the Kiosks in Rongai.  She gets on average $ 2 per day from the sale of milk. This assists her to cater for her day to day expenses. Veronica has a small stall in Rongai where she sells Tomatoes, Carrots, Onions, Kales and Peas. Though much of her stock is bought from the city market, Veronica also sells Kale from her garden. Veronica’s stall is a long Tuesso route. This route is the main entrance to Kware slum area-Rongai and many people use the same route. Veronica is able to make a sale of $ 7 per day. Veronica would wish to buy a hybrid dairy cow which will give her more milk. With good livestock management she believes she would be in a position to supply 30litres of milk per day. This will definitely increase her income and will reduce the burden of sourcing school fees for her children in future.

loans.use: Veronica would like to buy a hybrid dairy cow.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a single woman, a mother of two children and both in school. Her first born, James Ndungu is in St Joseph Secondary School in Kiambu- Central Kenya. The other is in standard eight, the last class in primary school in Kenya. Mary is very active and hardworking; she serves as the secretary in her self-help group.

Mary started her business of selling scrap metal in 2002 in Industrial area Nairobi. She later joined WEEC in 2004. Since then, she has received several loans to boost her business. Her first loan was USD 60 and she paid it very well. Mary currently collects about 200 kgs a day, which she sells to, brokers in Nairobi industrial area. Now that the demand is increasing, she would like to employ another person to help her in collected the scrap metal as well as transporting it to the buyers.

loans.use: Mary wants to increase the tonnage of scrap metal she buys from the rural area of Kiambu.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane was born 31 years ago in Kiambu Kenya. She is a single mother with two children. After finishing her secondary level education, she could not continue to college because her father could not afford to pay her tuition and instead he opted to educate other children to at least the same level like hers.

Her father gave her USD 60 to start a small business. She bought two piglets which she looked after for 6 months and later sold them. She made a profit of USD 150, it has been her business ever since. In 2003, Jane joined WEEC and received a loan of USD 150. She bought 6 piglets which she looked after for 6 months to make sure they are big enough. Jane paid her loan promptly and made good money, she does not bother the Dad any more and she is able to pay her children’s school fees.

loans.use: Jane would like to buy about 7 pigs of different age in order to have a steady supply.

loans.name: Faith

texts.en: Faith was born 34 years back and she is married with two children. She has been the group secretary of Kanunga Hope Women Group since it was started in 2003. Faith joined WEEC in 2003, received training in business management and later, was given a loan of USD 150 which enabled her to start a small business. Prior to this, she used to growing and selling vegetables in Kiambu Town and Westlands Nairobi. Her family has a small piece of land where she grows vegetables however; the income is not enough to meet her family requirements. She is yet to start rearing pigs because they sell like hot cakes.

loans.use: She would like to buy 15 piglets and all the medicine required for treating them.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is a hard working lady, a mother of 7 and a member of Mercury Women Group. She is a typical subsistence farmer and that’s where she gets her income to support her family. She has 3 dairy cows, goats and she sells milk to Kangema town. She also grows tea and has coffee trees on half acre of land. The tea board of Kenya buys her tea at $ 35 per month while coffee’s income comes twice a year around $80 per harvest. This loan will assist her because she wants a hybrid goat, which will improve the local breed, which grows very fast, and thus, she will realize her returns as soon as possible.

loans.use: She would like to buy a hybrid goat.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 38 years of age, married and a mother of four. Her children are all in primary school. She has been a member of mercury women group for the last two years. She saves with group and her savings have accumulated to $225. She sells mainly maize grains, beans, Irish potatoes and vegetables. She earns about $28 a day and this helps her to buy the necessary items to be used at home. She is working very hard to give her children a better life than what she got.

loans.use: Mary has been saving some money and she wants a top up to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en: Nancy was born 43 years ago. She is married to a good man who supports her initiatives and they have 6 children. Two are in secondary school while the rest are in primary school. She works hard to make sure that her children get good education and the basic necessities of life. She sells milk and Napier grass. Milk sales contribute $28 whereas Napier grass contributes $ 71 per month. With an additional cow, she will have more milk and her income will increase gradually. This will help her to give the necessary support to her family.

loans.use: She would like to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Salome

texts.en: Salome is a very hard working lady and it’s from this that she has managed to educate her 5 children to college level. She earns her income from selling vegetables and milk from her farm. She has a diary cow, dairy goats and a banana plantation. She gets about $71 per month from all her business activities. She has a small piece of land but she utilizes it to the optimum. With improved seeds and food supplements for the cows, she is sure that her productivity will increase and thus, increase income will be realized in a short while.

loans.use: Salome wants to buy dairy meal, improved seeds and agrochemicals

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary is a lady who inspires other ladies in her group because of her work. She is the secretary of Mercury Women Group a post she got without contesting with any one. She is a mother of six; five are independent while the last-born is in college. She encourages fellow group members to educate their children because it is the only everlasting gift a parent can give to a child. She is a farmer and grows bananas, maize, beans and tea on a small scale. She also sells milk from her dairy cows and this is her major source of income. She earns about $ 128 per month from all her businesses. She believes she can increase her income if she applies improved methods of farming.

loans.use: She would like to buy improved seeds to increase production of vegetables

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is married to a wonderful husband who contributes to the family welfare with $ 42 per month. They have two children and expecting another in a few months to come.  She is a mixed farmer; she grows vegetables, maize, beans and bananas. In addition, she sells milk from her own cows and it has helped her a lot in looking after her family and in enhancing her quest for financial freedom.

loans.use: Grace wants to buy dairy meal for her cows to increase milk production.

loans.name: Aima

texts.en:
This is a group loan request submitted by the women’s tontine

Djouromfouk-Houssel, represented by Aima S..  Founded

over ten years ago in the riverside village of Mlomp in southern  

Senegal, the women of Djouromfouk-Houssel engage in a wide

variety of commercial activities, including:

 

 
  • Growing produce such as tomatoes, lettuce, corn and manioc in their household gardens for sale both in the village market and to nearby hotels
  • Production and sale of homemade vegetable preserves and marmalade
  • Fabrication of hand-dyed cloth for use in making traditional clothing
  • Weaving mats and baskets from palm fronds to be sold in the village market

This loan will finance the expansion of the above microbusiness activities.  Planned investments include: the purchase of a greater quantity of seeds and basic gardening supplies (watering cans, hoes, rakes, etc.) as well as raw materials for the group members’ artisanal activities (sugar and spices for marmalade production, fabric and dyes for cloth-dying); and transportation of the finished goods to market.

loans.use: Purchase of gardening equipment and craft materials

loans.name: Madeleine

texts.en:
This is a group loan to be shared by the ten members of the women’s tontine Ayidjidjo, represented by Madeleine D..  Based in the village of Oussouye on the banks of the Casamance River in southern Senegal, the Ayidjidjo group engages in long-distance trade, transporting goods produced in Oussouye to distant markets where the demand for them is high and returning with products that are in short supply in Oussouye.  Typical products of Oussouye exported by the members of Ayidjidjo include:

  
  • Brooms made from palm fronds
  • Palm oil (used in traditional cooking throughout West Africa)
  • Millet oil (used by traditional healers to treat bone fractures)
  • Soap made from crushed oil palm nuts

Madeleine and her associates have requested a loan to scale up their inter-regional trade activities by purchasing greater quantities of locally produced goods and investing in their transportation to the markets of other regions.

loans.use: Long-distance trade: wholesale purchase and transport to market of local village products

loans.name: Ndèye Bineta

texts.en:
This is a group loan to be shared by the women’s tontine Daara Seydina Limamou Laye, represented by Ndèye Bineta T..  Based in the old fishing village of Yoff on the Dakar peninsula, the members of Daara Seydina Limamou Laye sell homemade juices and syrups made from typical West African produce such as the dried flowers of the bissap plant, ginger, tamarind, “monkey bread” (pulp from the seed pods of the baobab tree), yams, and mangoes.  The loan requested by the group will be invested in the expansion of their juice and syrup business, financing:

  
  • The wholesale purchase of input ingredients: bissap, tamarind, sugar, ginger, “monkey bread”, lemons, yams and mangoes
  • The purchase of equipment and production materials: large buckets and pots, manual juicing mills, water, gas fuel, and jars
  • Transportation of the finished products to market

loans.use: Production and marketing of juices and syrups

loans.name: Fatou Sèye

texts.en:
This is a group loan to be shared by the eight members of the women’s tontine Sant ak Kooluté, represented by Fatou Sèye D..  Located in the traditional fishing village of Yoff, the Sant ak Kooluté group has long specialized in producing the batiks and other vibrant hand-dyed fabrics that are used to make traditional clothing here in Senegal.  In addition to their main occupation of cloth-dying, the members of Sant ak Kooluté collaborate in a wide variety of modest income-generating activities, from raising chickens and vegetable gardening to sewing and crafting artisanal dolls.  The funding from this loan will be used to expand the Sant ak Kooluté cloth-dying business, including the purchase of a greater variety of blank fabrics and dye colors.

loans.use: Purchase of cloth-dying materials

loans.name: Coumba

texts.en:
This is a group loan to be shared by the members of the women’s tontine Ndiofor, represented by Coumba S..  The women of Ndiofor all live in Palmarin, a coastal fishing village surrounded by the vast salt flats and mangroves of the Saloum River delta region in central Senegal.  Coumba and her associates plan to “engage in modest trading at first in order to build up a fund large enough to start investing in wholesale and retail trade.”  They have therefore applied for a loan to be invested in scaling up the production and sale outside the village of three distinctive Palmarin products:

  

1)  Sea salt:  Salt harvesting in Palmarin involves dissolving slabs of natural sea salt deposits in boiling water to remove the sand, then grinding it into table salt.  Sea salt from the Saloum delta region has long been exported all over West Africa. 

  

2)  Smoked fish:  Fish purchased from village fishermen is preserved by covering and smoking over a wood fire.  Smoked fish is an essential ingredient in Senegalese cooking – giving the national dish, ceebu jen, its distinctive flavor – and is therefore in high demand throughout the country.

3)  Dried clams:  The women of Palmarin collect clams at low tide, shell them and sprinkle them with salt, and leave them to dry in the sun.  Dried clams are a popular addition to stews and sauces all over Senegal. 

 

All three of these products are light and non-perishable, making them ideal for long-distance trade.  Loan financing will not only allow the Ndiofor group to purchase larger quantities of salt, fish and clams from their fellow villagers, but also to invest in the transportation of the finished products to more distant markets where they command higher prices.

  

Background

  Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group.  Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, known as tontines.  Commonly organized by groups of twenty to thirty housewives who live in the same village, the tontines provide poor women throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities.  Repayment rates within these associations are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members.  However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income.  This has prevented the traditional tontines from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities.  Senegal Ecovillage Microfinance (SEM) works with our partner organization CRESP to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance.

loans.use: Production/sale of salt, smoked fish and dried clams

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Daba

texts.en:
This is a group loan to be shared by the members of the women’s tontine Bili, located in the village of Ndiaye Ndiaye and represented by Daba D..  The women of Bili are artisans specializing in the production of traditional clay ovens, which hold heat better than metal stoves and continue to be popular with households all over Senegal for cooking and heating in the cold months of January and February.  Daba and her associates have requested a loan for the expansion of their clay oven business, including the bulk purchase of input materials (clay, root fibers and crushed shells) and transportation of the finished ovens to nearby village markets.

  Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group.  Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, known as tontines.  Commonly organized by groups of twenty to thirty housewives who live in the same village, the tontines provide poor women throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities.  Repayment rates within these associations are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members.  However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income.  This has prevented the traditional tontines from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities.  Senegal Ecovillage Microfinance (SEM) works with our partner organization CRESP to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance.

loans.use: Production/sale of clay ovens

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is not married and has two children.She lives in Buza area in Dar es Salaam.Amina owns a small canteen near the Dar es Salaam Harbour. She sells cold drinks,breakfast and lunch to mostly harbour workers.Amina has received entrepreneurship and business training from Hans Said Foundation and Equal Oportunities Trust Fund (EOTF) in Dar es Salaam.
 On usual working hours her business is normally flocked with customers in need of services.She needs to expand her business by adding dining chairs and tables,food saving dishes and stock of cold drinks. To facilitate this expansion she is in need of USD 750 as a working capital. Amina’s dream is to have one day a professional catering business.

loans.use: EXPANDING THE BUSINESS

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Patrick wants to incease his stock of produce. He sells maize, millet, cassava, and many of the Ugandan staple foods. There is a lot of demand for his goods, and he wants to buy produce now at low prices. He will then keep them in store so that he can sell them after harvesting season when the price

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is 28 years old, married with three children. Sarah is a committed member of her church in Nkoroi. They hold meetings for the young single mothers - the meetings have made the young mothers to dedicate their lives to God and start up income generating activities. Sarah also assists her two younger brothers who were left by their mother when she passed away. The two are in primary school at the moment, she provides books and uniforms. Sarah has attended several trainings under WEEC program. Grace’s group runs a revolving fund and it was started in 2003. She has been the group treasurer for the last 3 years. Sarah’s husband was employed as a matatu driver. She asked her husband to save part of his salary and after two years she took a loan added it to the husband’s savings and they bought a reconditioned matatu. The husband has been operating the matatu for two years. The income from the matatu has enabled the family to purchase a small plot where they have built their home. Though the matatu is still making some money, Sarah would like to sell off the matatu add more money to the proceeds and purchase a better one. Sarah’s basic management course has enabled her keep good track of their matatu business.

loans.use: Sarah wants to buy a used Matatu (Mini-bus) better than what she currently has.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice is 54 years old, married with 7 grown up children. She is a member of Korea PCEA church and a member of mother’s guild. She is a part time preacher and prays for people in jail and frequently visits Tumaini children’s home for street children to encourage them. Alice loves farming; she keeps cows, sheep and has a farm where she grows maize, beans, peas and potatoes. Alice gets her income from selling milk to the neighbors and the nearby hotels. Before the drought period, Alice was selling 15 litres of milk from her 2 cows. Unfortunately, she could manage to buy hey and other feeds in the dry season and this made her sell them. The cows did not fetch much due to poor feeding. Alice had established good clientele and clients tell her that her milk was good unlike others who add in water to earn more. It is from this that she wants to give it a second try, well prepared to handle all calamities.

loans.use: Alice wants to buy two hybrid dairy cows.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace was born 50 years ago, married with 5 children. Her last born is in secondary school. Grace dedicates part of her day to God’s work. She believes that people must participate in God’s work for he is the provider. She is a member of PCEA church in Nkoroi and the Chairlady of the Woman’s guild, the leader of the boys and girls brigade. Also she is a Sunday school teacher. She also heads the Oloika district as a Deacon. Disciplined and time conscious, she is able to do her church duties with a lot of dedication and thoroughness. She is the secretary of Oloika progressive women group, a very strong group whose books are well kept. Grace has been keeping poultry for many years. She keeps 400 layers at a time. She has a good market in Nkoroi which is an upcoming busy trading centre. She sells the eggs to her neighbors and also in the many kiosks that have come up. Grace has employed one person who assists her to run the project. Grace uses poultry manure in her two plots of land to where she grows maize. She sells the green maize at Kiserian market and gets some extra income. Grace would like to put up an extra poultry house that will house 400 more layers to enable her rear more chicks. With an average of 700 layers at a time, she will be able to supply eggs to Nkoroi, Kandisi, Rimpa areas (all these are upcoming busy trading centers and the demand of farm products is high). She intends to buy a bicycle so as to make the distribution work easier and faster.

loans.use: Grace wants to build a new house for the chicken, buy extra 400 layers, and buy a bicycle to transport eggs.

loans.name: Nancy Wanjiru

texts.en: Nancy is 39 years old and has 6 children. She is a Lay leader in her church St. Micheal church. Nancy coordinates the women’s activities in assisting the needy. Nancy also assists 5 children of her brother in law who died. She pays the school fees for them. Nancy owns a plot at Kware Slum area. She has put up 13 rental rooms and the income per room is USD 12. Nancy wants to put up 7 more rooms. She had bought 56 Iron sheets but due to financial constraints she could not buy the other building materials. Completion of the 7 rental rooms would help Nancy realize more rental income. Therefore paying school fees for all the children will be easier and they will be able to get other necessities at school. To supplement the rental income, Nancy sells Charcoal; she sells 15 sacks in a week. The income from the charcoal is used for buying food and other household items.

loans.use: Nancy wants to build seven rental rooms.

loans.name: Grace Njeri

texts.en: Grace is 48 years old and has 6 children. Grace has lived in Kware slum area for over 30 years. In 2005, Kajiado county council allocated the Kware plots to the residents who had lived in that area for many years and had built small semi permanent homes. Grace is one among the lucky ones who benefited from this good gesture. Grace has built a house for her family  in this plot and has also put up 11 small semi-permanent rooms which she rents at USD 7 per room. Grace wants to build better rooms that can fetch USD 14.7. This means that her income will increase, thus she will have no difficulty in repaying her loan. To supplement her rental income, she has rented a two acre farm where she grows Maize, beans and peas. She sells the produce at Soko Mjinga market in Rongai assisted by her two daughters. After selling the produce she gives them part of the income. In this way her daughters are able to cater for some of their needs.

loans.use: Grace would like to build permanent rental rooms.

loans.name: Sovanara

texts.en:
E. Sovanara came to the CREDIT office with his mother, Ngen Sophan. He was requesting a $1,000 loan to invest in his food sales business and she came as his guarantor. Sophan must trust her son to guarantee such a loan. She is confident because Sovanara has successfully completed his first two loan cycle and was able to improve his house and to start the business.

Sovanara and his wife can make around $5 per day in cooking and selling food to the factory workers. Sometimes Sovanara is also earning some extra money as a moto-taxi. They have never been late in their repayment schedule because they save on a daily basis.

With his 3rd loan, he decided to buy a second motorbike. He will spend $800 in a strong second-hand motorbike and will keep the old one in case of emergency. Sovanara will use the remaining $200 to buy spices but also to cover the delayed payments he is granting to some of his clients.

In the future, the family has a plan to start another business. They would like to buy a cow and raise it for its calves.

loans.use: Purchase motorbike and invest in fod business

loans.name: Sophat

texts.en:
P. Sophat is living with her husband and two children in a small but decent house in Phnom Penh. She sells food in front of her house for $10 daily income while her husband is a government officer and earns a $25 monthly salary. In addition, P. Sophat is renting three rooms in the house she owns next to hers. She earns $115 per months.

 

P. Sophat applied for this $800 loan because she would like to have a new house built for her mother, in her hometown in Svay Rieng province. Her mother is living alone and doesn’t want to come to live in Phnom Penh so she needs a decent house. The house will cost $1,000 approximately, $150 for the labor and $850 for the materials.

loans.use: Build new house

loans.name: Liep

texts.en:
N. Liep is living with her nine children in a very busy, noisy and happy house. She usually stays at home and takes good care of the youngest children but at the same time she is a successful business woman. She completed her 10th cycle with CREDIT a few days ago. She always repaid the installments on time.

 

On her backyard, Liep is now raising three female pigs; the three of them are pregnant. If nothing wrong happens, she can expect an important income from the sale.

 

To repay this loan, Liep is relying on her eldest children. One son is a construction worker and makes $3 daily. One daughter is factory worker for $80 per month while another is advertising for a very popular beer company for $100.

 

Liep budgeted her loan use very cautiously. She reserved $400 for purchasing a motorbike for the family so that they will save money on transportation everyday. Another $250 will be spent to purchase 5 additional pigs’ cubes while the remaining $350 will be used to repair their house.

loans.use: Buying a motorbike, 5 pigs’ cubes and repairing their house.

loans.name: Somat

texts.en: M. Somat lives with his mother and older sister. His mother is in poor health and is currently in the hospital. M. Somat feels responsible for his family, and desires to provide a good income for them. M. Somat used to be a motor taxi driver. However, he has been out of work for the last 10 days because his moto bike was stolen. During this time of unemployment he has been assisting his sister in her cake baking business. However, he would like to be able to earn additional income for the family; therefore, he is applying for a loan for $700 so that he may purchase a tuk tuk (a type of passenger taxi cart which is attached to a motor bike). The entire $700 will be spent on the tuk tuk. As a motor taxi driver M. Somat earned about $5 a day. After consulting his brother-in-law, who is currently a tuk tuk driver, M. Somat anticipates being able to earn about $12.50 a day with the new tuk tuk.  M. Somat looks forward to being able to earn money for his family again, and even raise their standard of living with the increase in income that he anticipates from the tuk tuk.

loans.use: Purchase Tuk Tuk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase motor bike and sewing supplies

loans.name: Sy Tha

texts.en:
P. Sy Tha is a caring father of three sons and one daughter. He currently drives a passenger taxi cart (tuk tuk), and earns about $12.50 a day. He is applying for a loan for $1,000 in order to purchase another tuk tuk, so that his son-in-law may join him in the business. The tuk tuk costs $1,380, but he plans on paying some of it from his current savings. P. Sy Tha's wife sells vegetables at the market and earns about $7.50 per day. His daughter works in a local factory and earns $60 each month. His three sons attend school every day.

 

He is excited about the increased income that adding another tuk tuk to the family business will bring. He hopes to be able to build his family a cement home in the future; their current home is made of wood. He believes that he will be able to increase his family's standard of living as a result of this loan.

loans.use: Purchase Tuk Tuk

loans.name: Donald

texts.en: Donalds lives in Buza area, on the outskirts of Dar es Salaam.He owns a vegetable and fruits stall where he sells different fruits and vegetables items.He fetch some of the fresh produce like tomatoes and spinaches from local farmers near his residence.Other farm produce like oranges,bananas and pineaples come from nearby regions.Donald need to expand his business to meet a risen demand from his clients by having enough stock.He is planning to have cages for produts hygiene and attractive display.He also planning to have a bicycle to help him fetch some locally produced produce from nearby areas. To fulfill these requirements he is in need of USD 750,to subsdize his capital.

loans.use: BUSINESS EXPANSION

loans.name: Leandro

texts.en:
ENGLISH 

Leandro B. runs a small but efficient manufacturing operation in Guayaquil, Ecuador. He concentrates his efforts on making bed railings and other pieces of bedroom furniture. He supplements his business by selling mattresses and other complementary items. He operates from 8:00 AM to the 6:00 PM and his primary clients are the people from his community who he has served for over 10 years.  Leandro needs a loan of $1,200, to buy more iron, wood, shellac, etc. It was observed that he has good family stability and ownership of a small truck in order to transfer his merchandise. Leandro was born in Ventanas has 1 child with his wife and owns his own house. He has 19 years of work experience in manufacturing.

SPANISH

 

Leandro B. tiene 39 años, nació en Ventanas tiene 1 hijo,  esta unión libre con su señora, posee casa propia. Tiene un negocio de Elaboración y venta de camas y rejas, ubicado en el mismo domicilio de su casa,  su clientela son todos los moradores de la comunidad y clientes de otras zonas, su   experiencia la tiene desde  hace 19 años pero en esa dirección esta hace 10 años,   la atención  al público es de las 8:00 AM hasta las 18:00PM,   él necesita el préstamo  de $ 1,200,   para comprar más hierro, madera, laca, etc.  se pudo observar que ellos tienen buena estabilidad familiar inclusive tienen una pequeña camioneta de segunda para poder trasladar su mercadería

loans.use: Leandro will use the loan capital to fund the purchase of newer bed-making materials

loans.name: Laura

texts.en:
ENGLISH

 Laura Holguin runs a small business where she sells perfumes and cosmetic products. Part of her time is spent selling products out of her home while the other part is spent traveling around her community making sales to friends and acquaintances. She works from 8:00 AM and as late as 10:00 PM trying to sell her products. She is requesting a loan of $685 in order to buy in bulk and diversify her inventory. She has experience in this type of business for 19 years and her clientele are all inhabitants that live around her neighborhood. Laura was born in Guayaquil, she is 49 years old, and is single mother with 1 son.

SPANISH 

 Laura H., nació en  Guayaquil,  tiene 49 años de edad,  es madre soltera  tiene 1  hijo, posee casa propia. Su negocio es de Venta de perfumes y cosméticos , el  negocio esta ubicado en su casa, tiene una experiencia de 19 años,  sus clientes son todas las personas que viven a su alrededor, y ella sale a las empresas y amigos a vender,    ella    atiende a partir  de las 8:00AM hasta las 20:00PM, ella necesita $   685,00 para poder comprar más productos y poder aprovechar  los precios de oferta, se pudo observar que es una persona trabajadora, y  emprendedora, la misma que sostiene sola su hogar.

loans.use: Laura is asking for this loan in order to diversify her supply of perfumes

loans.name: Kléber

texts.en:
ENGLISH 

Kleber V. owns a small business where he sells fabrics and makes clothes. He works in making adjustments, new designs and creating custom fabrics. His business is run out of a rented location where he has access to attract clients from the community. Kleber needs $685 to be able buy materials like: fabrics, threads, scissors, and a mannequin. He was born in Manabi, he is 39 years old, he is single father with 2 sons and lives in an apartment which was inheritance from his parents. He has 15 years of experience in this type of business. He works from 7:00am to the 18:00pm, and appears to be very committed and hardworking.

SPANISH

Kléber V.,  nació en  Manabí, tiene 39 años de edad,  es padre soltero, tiene 2 hijos, vive en un departamento que es herencia de los padres Posee un negocio de Confección de ropa, alquila un local en la avenida principal, sus clientes son todas las personas de la comunidad, su experiencia es de 15 años en esta actividad, él atiende a partir  de las 7:00 AM hasta las 18:00PM,  él  necesita $ 685, para poder comprar materiales como: telas, hilos, juego de tijeras, una moldeadora, se  pudo observar que es una persona trabajadora, y  emprendedora.

loans.use: Kleber needs $685 to be able buy materials like: fabrics, threads, scissors, and a mannequin.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monicah is married with four children. Her husband is a lorry driver and distributes cement to various hard wares from Athi Town to Thika Town.

Monicah is a choir member of Kirigu Anglican Church and participates in various community work in Kirigu.

Monicah is a farmer and sells maize, beans, Potatoes and fruits. She has been in this business for more than 33 years. Every month, she is able to make a profit $57 from selling maize to traders in SabaSaba, Muranga, Thika and Nairobi.

loans.use: Monicah would like to buy a plot of land and build rental rooms.

loans.name: Judy

texts.en: Judy is hard working and an active member of Kahumbu Hannah Women’s Group. Judy is 32 years old, married and has two boys and one girl. Her husband is a fine artist and shares his income with the entire family. Judy started business with a grocery and later an electronics shop in 2000. She sells mobile phones and their accessories; electric cables, iron boxes, Radios, CDs and small CD players. She started with and initial capital of $440 and since then, the business has been growing and today it is worth $1,428. This has been possible because of the business skills and financial support she received with other group members from WEEC. The business takes care of all the necessities at home and school fees for the children. The use of mobile phones increases every day and so do the sales and income.

loans.use: Judy wants to buy mobile phones and accessories to fill the gap in her stock.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is 40 years old and married with 4 children. She is a secondary school Teacher at Ndonga Secondary School. At group level, Catherine is the secretary and a devoted Christian.

Catherine operates a retail shop which sells clothes, Cosmetics, shoes and ornaments. Her business is progressing very well and on average she gets a profit of about $150 per month. Her children are in school and she does not have problems in raising their school fees because of her business is doing very well. She wants her business to grow and later support her family when she retires from her Teaching service.

loans.use: She would like to buy dresses, skirts and blouses that are fashionable that enhances appeal to her customers.

loans.name: Felishina

texts.en: Mercy is 40 years old, married with 6 children. Two of her children are already married and have their homes whereas the rest are still in secondary and primary schools. Mercy has been the Treasurer of Kagaa Witeithie Women Group a position she has held since January 2005. She is trustworthy, a dedicated and hard working member of the group. Mercy has a retail shop at Ngurweini trading center. She sells maize flour, rice, sugar, and other household items. She also has a small farmland where she grows maize, beans and vegetables for home consumption and some for selling. In addition, she has a dairy cow and this gives her milk for sell as we as for home consumption. Most of her income comes from her retail shop and others supplement. Her monthly net income is about $73 and this is very low to support her family in future.

loans.use: Mercy wants to stock maize flour, wheat flour, rice, Soap, salt, Maize and beans.

loans.name: Getrude

texts.en: Getrude is married and has 3 children; she was born 26 years ago and started business when she was only 16 years of age. She started by selling vegetables from farmers and selling it to customers in Muranga Town. The business to date is doing very well and she has introduced other products, milk and cereals.  She wants to use the loan for paying school fees and keep paying back monthly because her business cannot generate $ 125 at once but rather can generate monthly installments to pay back the loan.

loans.use: Getrude would like to pay school fees for her children and to restock her retail shop.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy is 40 years old, married with 6 children. Two of her children are already married and have their homes whereas the rest are still in secondary and primary schools. Mercy has been the Treasurer of Kagaa Witeithie Women Group a position she has held since January 2005. She is trustworthy, a dedicated and hard working member of the group. Mercy has a retail shop at Ngurweini trading center. She sells maize flour, rice, sugar, and other household items. She also has a small farmland where she grows maize, beans and vegetables for home consumption and some for selling. In addition, she has a dairy cow and this gives her milk for sell as we as for home consumption. Most of her income comes from her retail shop and others supplement. Her monthly net income is about $73 and this is very low to support her family in future.

loans.use: Mercy wants to stock maize flour, wheat flour, rice, Soap, salt, Maize and beans.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is a very young lady aged 20 years and has 2 children. Grace is hard working and very active in her church where she is a choir member and Women’s Guild. She sells used and new clothes at Kagumoini Shopping Centre. She has also a small piece of land where she grows onions and vegetables. She sells most of the vegetables but grows some for home consumption. For clothes to be sold there should always be something new to attract customers thus, the need for a loan to ensure that customers are maintained by stocking new materials.

loans.use: Grace wants to buy a bale of 1st class used clothes and new materials

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en: Pauline was born 38 years ago, she is married and has 4 children; three are in primary and one in secondary school. She is the chairlady of Catholic Pioneer Movement and a good member of the group. She is a farmer by occupation and mainly grows vegetables and cereals. She gets her income from the sell of vegetables, milk and cereals. Milk produced is mainly for sale and a little is kept aside for home consumption. Her monthly income from business is about $87, this is not enough to pay her daughter’s school fees. However, she can pay back the loan because its spread through out the year.

loans.use: Pauline would like to pay school fees for her daughter

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 54 years old, married and has 3 children. She is lucky to have a very small family and now has only one child who is still in college. Mary is an active member of Gathigia Christian International Church and she is the Organizing Secretary. She grows vegetables and sells milk from her own cows. She sells on average10 litres of milk every day, this gives her $2.85. The sales from vegetables are very minimal on average she earns $14 per month. She plans to keep supplying vegetables all through out the year by using irrigation method. Water is rationed and if you have a water tank then, you have the opportunity to store enough for cows and irrigation.

loans.use: Mary would like to buy a water tank.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce was born 43 years ago in Gathiga, Lower Kabete in Kiambu Kenya. She is married with five children. Her first born is in her final year in Kirigiris Nursing College. Her second born is schooling in Uganda at St Kizito High school while the third born is at St Austin University, Kenya. All others are in primary school. Joyce has been a youth matron for many years. She is a member of Catholic Women Association. (CWA)-Gathiga Catholic Church. Joyce started business by selling porridge in Marigiti in Nairobi; she later opened a retail shop in Mwimuto in Kiambu. The business grew and later they bought a cab which started operating in Nairobi Central Business District. Some years back, she was transporting potatoes from Kinangop Kenya to sell them in Nairobi. While doing her business, she would save by buying dairy cows; right now she has seven and sells milk to Nairobi Hotels. Last week she opened a milk bar on Kirinyaga Road Nairobi and it is doing well so far. Her desire is to satisfy her customers’ needs to make sure that there is milk all the time. She joined WEEC in 2002 and in 2004 she received a loan of USD 715 and paid it in time.

loans.use: Joyce wants to improve her business premises and buy more milk from other suppliers to meet the demand.

loans.name: Elodia

texts.en: Elodia was born in Monterrey, Mexico. She is married and has four sons. To develop her family's economy she decided to invest all her savings in a Taco Kiosk. She started her micro business in 1996 with a little help from one of her sons and they called it “TACOS KOKIS” and actually sell Tacos of many different flavors every morning. Elodia's kiosk lets her educate all her sons and two of them graduated from a technical program, and actually all of them are married. She has two people as employees, one is her daughter in-law and the other one is her nephew. This is because she receives 60 tacos orders on average every morning. Cecilia works outside her house and she will use this loan to grow her business in front of her house because the clients suffer the weather inclemencies. For example, in the case of rain or very cold weather, her sales increase as well.

loans.use: She works outside her house and with this loan she wants to invest in her business because her clients suffers the weather inclemencies, for example, if it is raining or maybe is so cold outside, for this reason she wants to grow her business infront of her house.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia was born in San Luis Potosi, but she has lived in Monterrey for 30 years with all her family. She moved to Monterrey looking for new and better oportunities. She started her business by only selling her children's used clothing to her families and friends. Now she is successfully selling used clothing and new clothing (since 1994) and has two stores in diferents markets open only Wednesday and Friday. She is requesting this loan to purchase clothing because the new season is coming and she wants to be prepared. She will purchase more inventory for her two stores. Cecilia hopes that at the end of the year her sales increase approximately by 30%.

loans.use: Cecilia needs a loan to buy clothing now, becuse the new season is coming and she wants to be prepared and will get inventory for her two stores.

loans.name: Claudia

texts.en: Claudia is a young housewife who is 25 years old and has 3 children. When she was younger she lived in a convent called "Casa de Jesus" and part of her education was obtained there. The nuns taught her how to seam, how to handmake articles, and to paint and cook. After this experience she finally ends her studies at the school and she has no more education. Claudia started to work by herself doing table cloths, napkins, and all type of handmade textile articles which are very much appreciated in the Christmas season and at children's parties as well. As all of her work is handmade and she does not have any employees who help her, she needs to be ready for the Christmas season, so she needs to start to work overtime. This is so she can purchase materials this month. Claudia is a very entrepreneurial woman because she does not only do home products, but she also works selling shoes by cataloge during the year because her handmade product earnings are only good until November and December.

loans.use: Purchase material for her business

loans.name: Sophap

texts.en: C. SoPhap is a caring mother of a son and a daughter.  She is requesting her first loan in the amount of $500. She currently works in a factory and earns $70 each month. Her husband drives a motor bike taxi, and earns about $1.75 each day. C. SoPhap is applying for this loan so that she may purchase a better motor bike for her husband. His current motor bike is old, and needs many repairs. They plan to sell the old motor bike and use the money the receive from the sale along with the $500 from the loan to purchase a better motor bike.With the new motor bike he should be able to increase business, and bring in increased income for the family. C. SoPhap looks forward to being able to increase the standard of living of her children as a result of this loan.

loans.use: Purchase motor bike

loans.name: Lina

texts.en: P. Lina is a hardworking single mother. In addition to caring for her three sons and two daughters, P. Lina owns a sewing business. She earns about $1.25 per day from her business. Her eldest son and eldest daughter both help provide for the family as well. Her daughter works in a factory and earns $60 per month, and her son earns about $40 per month. P. Lina is requesting this loan of $500 to purchase raw materials to make repairs on their home. She is looking forward to making their home safer and more comfortable for her family. In the future she would like to be able to add fruit sales to her sewing business in order to be able to provide a greater income for her family.

loans.use: Purchase raw materials to make repairs on home.

loans.name: Vanny

texts.en: K. Vanny is a very busy woman. In addition to her fruit sales business, she spends much time taking care of her four daughters, two sons, and grandmother. K. Vanny earns about $3.75 from her fruit sales each day. Her husband is a motor bike taxi driver, and earns about $2.50 a day. Her oldest son also works, and earns about $2.25 per day. She is applying for a $1,000 loan. She is planning to use $300 to help her husband purchase a new motor bike so that he can increase his taxi business. She plans to use the other $700 to help pay for the new home they would like to build. She is very excited about being able to provide her family with a better home, and she anticipates increased income from the new motor bike.

loans.use: Sell old motor bike and buy new, and build house.

loans.name: Enock

texts.en: Enock is married with three children.He lives in Kitunda area of Dar es Salaam.The area is well known for residents engaging themselves in animal keeping.Enock sells animal feeds to these animal keepers.He buys by-products of maize,cotton,palm carnels,sunflowers and other cereals and packs them in bags of 5kgs and 10 kgs ready for resale.Enock is planning to expand his business by adding to stock some other types of animal feeds which are professionally manufactured like broilers –mash and layers – mash for chickens .He also need a bicycle of which he will use to ferry  products purchased by his customers to their premises as an after sale service.Enock also keeps layers of which his wife is in-charge.He is planning to add the flock of these layers to subsidize his income in order to meet family requirements as well as school fees for his children. To meet his expectation Enock is in need of USD 750.

loans.use: WORKING CAPITAL

loans.name: Araceli

texts.en:
ENGLISH

Araceli is a very entrepreneurial woman. She is 42 years old and is married with 3 sons. She was born in the south of the state, Linares N.L., however she has 26 years living in Monterrey. She moved to this city because she had to study and also because she wanted to look for better opportunities. Araceli's business is selling clothing; whites (like towels and cloths of bed) and handmade products, which she sells in monthly installments between neighbors and friends. She has mini stores in popular markets but these are temporary because she has to move inside these markets from one place to another and she needs the loan to invest in materials and merchandise for her business. So her expectations in the short term are to establish her business in a fixed place inside these mini markets and also to teach how to make handmade products to her neighbors (and how to sell the material to do it as well). Christmas season is coming soon so she is very thrilled with her business idea.

SPANISH

Araceli es una mujer muy emprendedora, tiene 42 años de edad, esta casada y tiene 3 hijos. Ella es originaria de una comunidad al sur del estado: Linares N. L., sin embargo tiene 26 años de haber emigrado a Monterrey, para poder estudiar y buscar mejores oportunidades. Es comerciante y se dedica a la venta de ropa, blancos y manualidades, los cuales vende en abonos entre vecinos y amistades, ha logrado tener puestos semi fijos en mercados y esta solicitando un crédito de $4,000 a 4 meses porque necesita invertir en la compra de mercancía y materiales para las manualidades. Sus expectativas son ver a corto plazo su negocio ya mas establecido, incluso dar clases de manualidades entre sus vecinos y vender material. Se avecina una buena temporada (Navideña), por lo que esta muy entusiasmada con la idea de poder invertir un poco mas en su negocio.

loans.use: Purchase material and merchandise for her business

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
ENGLISH

Patricia is married and has 3 sons, her husband works at IMSS as an employee. To help with the family expenses, it is necessary that she start a business selling food every weekend (friday, saturday and sunday). On mornings she sells Barbacoa (it is a kind of boiled meat out into a taco) and Menudo (this is like a hot soup), and at nights she sell tacos, flautas and sopes (typical Mexican food) which are very acceptable for the people in her zone. Patricia's business is in front of her house, where she put a table and a mini grill. She has 10 years of doing this. She is requesting this loan to purchase raw materials for her business because in the school season her sales fall down and she needs to reactivate her business. She thinks that at the end of the year her business will grow by including in her menu tamales (another typical mexican food).

SPANISH

Patricia tiene un negocio de alimentos los fines de semana, viernes, sábado y domingo vende Barbacoa y Menudo, platillos que son muy demandados en su sector. Su esposo es empleado del IMSS, y tiene 3 hijos, para poder ayudar con los gastos de su casa, se vio en la necesidad de ponerse a vender alimentos y con muy buena aceptación los fines de semana por las mañanas vende Menudo y Barbacoa y por las noches Tacos, flautas y sopes. Su negocio lo tiene establecido en el frente de su casa en donde instala la parrilla, y la mesa para poder realizar la actividad, cuenta con mas 10 años dedicándose a esta actividad. Patricia esta solicitando un préstamo por la cantidad de $4,000 a 4 meses para invertir en Insumos, pues con la temporada escolar las ventas se vieron afectadas y necesita reactivar su negocio. Hacia finales de año piensa que podrá incrementar la variedad de su menú pues le demandan platillos propios de la época como son los tamales.

loans.use: To invest in raw material and to grow her business

loans.name: Parascovia

texts.en: Parascovia is a talented seamstress with a love of elegant clothing and ornate handicrafts. Just over a year ago, she decided to make a business out of her passion and began making wedding dresses and accessories. She sells her products from a small booth in her town’s shopping area to brides-to-be from all the surrounding locations. Parascovia’s dresses sell quickly, and she would now like to expand the production capacity of her business. To do so she needs a loan to fund the purchase of more material and other assorted supplies.

loans.use: Working Capital

payments.comment: Parascovia is happy to have paid back her loan in full.

loans.name: Valeriu

texts.en: Valeriu has long worked in the agricultural sector, and his experience shows in the quality of the crops he brings to market. At the peak of harvest season, he and his family rise before sunrise every day to prepare for the 20 km trip to the regional center where sellers await. A consultant for three different extension agencies in Moldova, Valeriu works hard to stay informed about market conditions and production methodologies, combining his knowledge of both to make his production decisions every year. He now wishes to purchase hybrid seeds for eggplants, peppers and tomatoes to ensure a resistant and productive crop for the next season.

loans.use: Seed Purchases

loans.name: Constantin

texts.en: Constantin lives in one of Moldova’s most wine production intensive regions. He knows and loves wine, as someone accustomed to working the vineyards and tasting the harvest. He sells most of the grapes from his own vineyards to the many local wineries, of course keeping a few for traditional house wine. In the future, he also hopes to open a small bed-and-breakfast to capture some of Moldova’s growing rural tourism market. For now, Constantin will try simply to further develop his vineyards, and for this needs a small cultivator, fertilizer and new vines.

loans.use: Vineyard Expansion

loans.name: Nicolae

texts.en: Nicolae, together with his family of four, grows vegetables for a living. Thanks to a self-constructed greenhouse, he begins seeding tomatoes and cucumbers early in the year for a first harvest in late May. The competitive advantage gained from the timing is supplemented by a convenient location, close to three different regional markets. Some of the seedlings are kept and planted in the fields for a second crop later in the year. Nicolae would like to build two more greenhouses, a large one to be used exclusively for tomatoes, and a smaller one for raising seedlings. For this he needs construction materials, including wood, plastic and accessories.

loans.use: Greenhouse Construction

loans.name: Vasile

texts.en: Vasile and his wife, with their young daughter and small farm, live a typical rural Moldovan life. Their vineyards are their pride and joy. Set on a scenic hilltop overlooking the valley and town where he lives, they occupy his every day in the growing and harvesting seasons. His vision for expansion is to plant grapes of a different type - the popular Isabella grape, which is preferred by wineries. To make it happen, he is in need of capital for the purchase of new vines and the fertilizer to help assure successful growth.

loans.use: Vineyard Plantation

loans.name: Vera

texts.en: Vera’s business idea was a simple one: buy new varieties of foods and goods to re-sell at the open-air market in her town. After giving much thought to the items she wished to stock (those previously unavailable), she went about purchasing them and securing a table at the market. Currently, she sells a variety of canned foods as well as an array of other products. Paying close attention to customer demand, Vera now wants to expand her offering with some dried food products. She needs a loan to procure these and to generally make more purchases in bulk to increase her profit margin.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Ilie

texts.en: Ilie is a farmer in rural Moldova, where irrigation is traditionally unreliable (rainfall) or expensive. He is specialized in watermelon and cabbage production on his hillside land plot. An innovative idea - use of a hilltop spring to pressurize a drip irrigation system without any need for energy usage - is currently being employed by other farmers in his town. Ilie wants to do likewise to ensure permanent and virtually cost free irrigation for his land, but first needs a loan to install the piping.

loans.use: Irrigation System

loans.name: Mihail

texts.en: Mihail has a vibrant little farm with his family, where chickens, ducks, geese, sheep and pigs are all to be found. The mainstay of the farm’s income, however, is pork sales. He currently has two female pigs, which he bought earlier this year, and the nine piglets which have since arrived. He plans to keep three of these for breeding and to sell the remaining ones for meat, either live or butchered at the farmers’ market. To grow his business, Mihail wants to buy two more sows and continue breeding piglets to sell next year.

loans.use: Animal Purchases

loans.name: Ecaterina

texts.en: Moldova’s market for honey and its byproducts is an active one. The many participants on the supply side are mostly small producers with beehives in the vicinity of their home villages. Ecaterina is one such honey supplier, having filled her backyard with hives last year. She currently has twenty-two families of bees, which she takes to the forest in the summer for pollen collection. When the harsh Moldovan winter comes around, the bees are left with a supply of their own honey for nutrition. Ecaterina sells honey, wax and medicinally valuable propolis to residents of her town and the surrounding region. She hopes to receive a loan to increase her business to encompass seventy families of bees.

loans.use: Beehive Purchases

loans.name: Ion

texts.en: Ion is a butcher by profession and a salesman by nature. He welcomes customers to his table with a big smile and proudly displays the various cuts of meat. He buys beef and pork live from farmers in the many villages surrounding his town and slaughters them himself, taking care to get the most efficient cuts from each. His reputation for good quality meat have earned this entrepreneur loyal customers, and to serve them better, Ion wishes to add chicken to his product offerings. He needs a loan to purchase the initial quantities of meat already prepared from a vendor in the city.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.en:
ENGLISH

Ana Maria is a divorced woman with 2 sons. She had to start to work by selling used clothing between her neighbor and friends because she needs to educate her sons. She purchases used clothing once a week in packages of 500 or 600 lbs. and in these packages the clothing is of different qualities. She then sell this clothing in a store located at “Mercado Campesino” (farmers market) in Monterrey every Friday, Saturday and Sunday. Additionally, she sells clothing to remarketers whom buy her merchandise in greater quantities. Actually, she has a contact who has offered her the opportunity to sell her clothing in outlets of big department stores (like JC Penney and Sears). So she needs to invest $2,305 but she only has $1,380, and for this reason Ana Maria needs a loan of $925 and 6 months to repay. She has to take advantage of this opportunity because this situation will eventually let her open a boutique with new and better quality of clothing. She will also gain new clients and more than she has now. This will help to be prepared for the new season and her earnings will grow as well.

SPANISH

Ana María, es una madre de familia divorciada y con 2 hijos, quién para salir adelante y poder darles educación comenzó a vender entre sus vecinos y amigos ropa usada. Ella compra una vez a la semana pacas de ropa de 500 ó 600 libras, en donde viene ropa, de diferentes calidades y las vende en Monterrey, en un puesto ubicado en el Mercado Campesino, los viernes, sábados y domingos. Adicionalmente, vende ropa a revendedores quienes le compran de mayoreo la mercancía. Actualmente tiene un contacto, quién le ofrece saldos de ropa de cadenas comerciales como Sears y JCPenney en donde necesita hacer una inversión de $25,000 de los cuales, solo cuenta con $15,000; es por lo anterior, que esta solicitando un prestamos por la cantidad de $10,000 a 6 meses, para poder aprovechar esta excelente oportunidad, pues estaría en condiciones de poder establecer una boutique con esta mercancía, y así poder captar un cliente diferente al que maneja en el mercado campesino, pues se trata de ropa de marca, en donde su margen de utilidad se elevaría considerablemente. Además de estar preparada para el cambio de temporada y tener bien surtido su negocio.

loans.use: To buy new clothing to open a boutique

loans.name: Mario Cesar

texts.en:
ENGLISH

Mario has more than 29 years selling pewter stoneware and he was born in Monterrey. He knew this business when he fell in love with his wife years ago, because his wife’s parents were doing this activity. When he was young he worked and when his job ended, Mario sold his house to stock the pots and frying pans. Actually in Monterrey there is no production of this kind of pots, which is why he must travel to the Saltillo city located in Coahuila to purchase his merchandise. He needs a loan for $475 and he will repay in 6 months. A very good season is coming because in September his demand increases so he needs to be prepared with merchandise. He has a store in the farmers market in which he sets up every weekend and as a complement of his activity he also sells natural products with a little help from one of his daughters.

SPANISH

Mario tiene más de 29 años de dedicarse a la venta de loza de peltre, él es originario de Monterrey, N. L., y esta casado.Conoció el negocio de la loza de peltre cuando se hizo novio de su esposa, ya que los papas de ella se dedicaban a esta actividad, y siendo aun joven, trabajaba y al terminar su jornada salía a vender casa por casa las ollas y sartenes. Actualmente en Monterrey se dejo de producir este tipo de vasijas, por lo que tiene que viajar a la ciudad de Saltillo, Coahuila para abastecerse de mercancía. A la fecha ocupa un crédito por la cantidad de $5,000 a 6 meses, pues se avecina una buena temporada, ya que desde el mes de septiembre la demanda de ollas tamaleras se incrementa, por lo que necesita estar preparado con suficiente mercancía. Tiene un puesto en el Mercado campesino en donde vende los fines de semana y complementa su actividad con la venta de productos naturales, con el apoyo de una de sus hijas.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Maria De Jesus

texts.en:
ENGLISH

Two years ago Maria de Jesus decided to sell shoes to help with the home expenses of her family. She thought that this activity was very practical because by doing it, she does not neglect her home and could take care of her sons. Years before she sold jewelry, but she left this business because she had to travel a lot to Guadalajara, Jalisco which is about 10 hours to Monterrey by bus and this was so difficult for her. Also she spent money in travel expenses so it was not advantageous. As she had a portfolio of clients already, she decided to find something different with demand and available to purchase in her city as well, so Maria de Jesus found her actual business of selling shoes and plastic articles by catalogue. She needs a loan for $850 and is asking for 6 months to repay the loan, because this time her shoe sales will increase for school season and for this reason she needs to invest in merchandise. She comments that this business makes her feel free and independent because her earnings are good and it is not necessary to request money from her husband for her basic expenses (and two of her three sons are in the university). She works for awhile every afternoon and every weekend she dedicates more time. She feels very happy with her achievements and Maria de Jesus does not discard the possibility of one day getting to have her own center of distribution.

SPANISH

Hace 2 años María de Jesús, decidió ponerse a vender calzado para ayudar con los gastos del hogar, consideraba que era una actividad muy práctica, ya que con ella no descuidaría su casa y el cuidado de sus hijos. Antes vendía joyería, pero dejo este negocio porque tenía que viajar a la ciudad de Guadalajara, Jalisco a más de 10 horas de distancia para traer la mercancía, y esto se le dificultaba mucho, además de tener que invertir en los gastos de viaje, y ya no le resultaba tan ventajoso. Como ya contaba con una cartera de clientes, decidió buscar algo que también tuviese demanda, pero que pudiese comprar en la misma ciudad, fue así como dio con la venta de calzado y vasijas de plástico, las cuales vende por catálogo y surte el pedido conforme lo demandan sus clientes. Esta solicitando un préstamo de $9,000 a 6 meses, pues en calzado se le han incrementado las ventas con motivo del regreso a clases de los niños, por lo que necesita invertir en mercancía. Ella comenta que gracias al negocio, se siente independiente, pues las ganancias son buenas y no necesita estar pidiendo dinero a su esposo para cubrir sus gastos más básicos. Ya que 2 de sus 3 hijos están estudiando en la universidad. Su negocio lo atiende un rato por las tardes y los fines de semana, que es cuando le dedica mayor tiempo. Se siente satisfecha con lo que esta logrando y no descarta la posibilidad de llegar a tener su propio centro de distribución bien establecido.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her business

loans.name: Shania

texts.en: Shania is married and has 5 children. She was born 42 years ago in Osotua, Isinya, and Kajiado district. She operates a restaurant near Saunyi quarry in Isinya and at the same time makes bead items for sale. The beadwork business supplements her income and does not take a lot of time assembling materials to make bracelets and belts. She has started to buy many items from other women because there is ready market by some one who exports them. This requires one to buy in large quantities in order to enjoy advantages of buying in bulk, which include trade discounts and transport economies of scale. She is optimistic her business will generate enough income to improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Shania wants to increase her stock of items made out of beads because she has been linked to some one who exports them.

loans.name: Siminkor

texts.en:
K. is a married woman aged 49 years and has 4 children. She is a dedicated group member of Osotua women Group a community based organization. She keeps her savings with the group and all members of the group are encouraged to save as a means of accumulating capital.

K. has been in business for over 20 years, she runs a small retail shop in Kepiro Trading centre and the major items sold include among others Sugar, salt, match boxes, maize flour, wheat flour, rice, cooking oil and vegetables. Her daily sales are in the range of $50 to $ 90. Because of having limited funds, she stocks after every two days thus, transport expenses are high and this reduces her profit margin. With a loan of $400, she will stock all the necessary items at least twice a month. She will also stock other items that are not in her shop at present which are frequently asked such as pishori rice. This means that her shop will be a one-stop shopping centre in a rural setting. She will be guaranteed of increased sales and high profit margin as well.

loans.use: She would like to buy 2 boxes of soap, a bag of sugar, 100 ropes and other household items for the shop.

loans.name: Simiton

texts.en: Simiton is a Maasai by tribe and they are famous for beadwork and cattle keeping. She was born 33 years ago in Isinya near the border of Kenya and Tanzania. She is married to a hard working and enlightened man who allowed her to do business unlike others who think that Women should not live home for any activity. She sells items made out of beads at Nairobi Maasai market and in Isinya Town. Her husband sells milk and when her business is low then, she helps her husband in buying and immediate selling of milk. Working together has helped them greatly in building a strong family and in sharing responsibilities. Their children are still young; two are in primary where as the other two are still very young for school. So far, they can afford to have good meals, medical care and send their children to school from the proceeds of their businesses. They hope the situation will be better as the country’s economy improves such that the price of milk in rural areas can increase from 28cents to 42 cents like in other Towns.

loans.use: Simiton wants to buy beads, belts, bags and other materials, which act as, base material where beads are attached.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn is the chairlady of Osotua women group. She is 33years old, married with 4 children. Her children are still young and all are in primary school. She operates a retail shop in Kipiro trading centre and mainly she sells house hold items which include among others: Sugar, Maize flour, vegetables, salt, and milk jugs. Her business is progressing and it’s helping her in providing all the necessities at home including medical care. She would like to stock her shop such that clients are not disappointed when they come to buy various household items. This will create customer loyalty a major contributor to business growth.

loans.use: She would like to restock her shop with Maize flour, cooking oil, salt, sugar, wheat flour and soap.

loans.name: Kakuu

texts.en: Kakuu is a member of Osotua women group a community based organization that encourages women to start up income generating activities. The group runs a group revolving fund and it has a bank account where members keep their savings. She is 42 years old, married and they have five children. She has been in business since 1984 and she been selling milk in Isinya Town for years. Since then, she is ever on the move finding opportunities to improve her life. She started raising steers in 2002 and the business was doing very well until 2005 when the whole area was almost destroyed by a prolonged drought. The climate since March this year favors farmers and life is back to normal in Maasai land. Kakuu now has three steers in different age groups and she will sell one at a time. She wants to keep six steers and at the end of six months, two will be ready for sell and this will give her good income to pay school fees for her children and to cover other necessities.

loans.use: She would like to buy six steers.

loans.name: Angela

texts.en: Angela is a young mother of a baby girl and she is 26 years of age. She is a primary school teacher who is not satisfied with the meager monthly salary paid by the government of Kenya.
