loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria lives in Kitunda area in Dar es Salaam.She is not married and has two children.One in primary school and another in secondary school.
Maria keeps layers and broilers nearby her residence.She is in a plan of adding the flock of chickens from 400 she usually kept to 600.Maria has to employ one person in her business to take charge of the increased stock. The expansion strategy need some additional funding as more chicks are to be added and a stock of poultry  feed.The expansion  plan will enable Maria pay for school fees for her secondary school children and increase income for her family. To implement her growth plan she need additional capital of  USD 400.

loans.use: BUSINESS EXPANSION

loans.name: Radka

texts.en:
Radka and her husband Atanas have a family walnut processing business in the Roma ghetto of Sliven, Bulgaria.  Radka and Atanas have two kids, aged 10 and 14.  Atanas drives all over Bulgaria purchasing walnuts in their shells and brings them back to Sliven.  In the family’s main room, Radka, Atanas, their two sons, and a variety of cousins, aunts and uncles shell the walnuts.  Atanas then takes the nuts to one of several walnut processing companies with whom he works, which then clean and package the nuts and distribute them into grocery markets across Bulgaria.  In a two-week processing period, the family nets 250BGN (160USD).

This loan will play a crucial role in increasing the amount of working capital available to Radka and Atanas.  Currently, they have to wait several weeks to be paid by the large companies after dropping off the shelled nuts.  During this waiting period, they do not have the funds on hand to purchase a new load of walnuts to shell… so they wait instead of work.  With this capital, they’ll be able to dramatically increase the velocity of their business, increasing by 50% – 75% the amount of nuts they can shell in a year.  

Radka is proud of the work ethic their business has instilled in their children, a laudable trait anywhere and one that is worthy of encouragement.  

The Roma, commonly referred to as gypsies, is a severely marginalized social group in the Balkans.

loans.use: Working capital

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Yordan

texts.en:
Yordan is a 35-year-old Roma living in Sliven, Bulgaria. For the last 10 years, Yordan has supported his wife and two children (aged 14 and 17) by his work with walnuts. Yordan drives around Bulgaria buying walnuts in their shells by the sack. Upon his return to Sliven, he weighs the sacks and gives each to one of his independent contractors. The contractor removes the walnuts from their shells and returns the shelled walnuts to Yordan. Weighing the sacks before their distribution lets Yordan know approximately how many kilos of shelled nuts should be returned, to prevent his contractors from siphoning off his nuts. Yordan provides work for approx 50 people for 5 days when he brings in a load of nuts to be shelled. Yordan then sells his walnuts at the major nut markets in Sofia and Burgas.

Currently, Yordan can afford to buy 2,000BGN (1,300USD) worth of walnuts at a time, which he sells 10 days later for 2,500BGN (1,625USD). After salaries and expenses (gas for his van to drive around Bulgaria buying and selling the nuts), Yordan nets approximately 200BGN (130USD), which he can do every two weeks or so. This loan will give him the capital to increase the amount of nuts he can buy at a time (nearly double), employing more people in the Roma ghetto of Sliven.

The Roma, commonly referred to as gypsies, is a severely marginalized social group in the Balkans.

loans.use: Working capital

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Karla Jasmina

texts.en:
My name is Karla S., I have been making and selling tortillas for six years. In the past months, the sales of tortillas has improved because I have two other young women helping me make and deliver the tortillas, which is one of the necessary ingredients in every food. I am studying through a distance course at the Universty, and my income helps me support my mother and brothers.

Loan Use: cornflour, firewood, lime.

Me llamo Karla S., me dedico a la elaboracion y venta de tortillas desde hace 6 años. En estos ultimos meses la venta de tortillas ha mejorado por lo que tengo otras 2 jovenes que me ayudan a la elaboracion y distribucion de las tortillas, que es uno de los ingredientes necesarios en cada comida. Actualmente estoy estudiando a distancia en la universidad, los ingresos que obtengo me ayudan con el sostenimiento de mi madre y hermanos.

loans.use: Compra de harina de maiz, leña, cal.

loans.name: Lourdes Melissa

texts.en:
In my community I am known as Melissa, I sell children's clothes, and also for men and women, as well as items for the home by commission. I have had my street vending business for five years, which has enabled me to attract loyal clientel, who prefer my low prices to those they find in the marketplace. My income helps me with family expenses and the studies of my children.

Loan Use: Purchase children's shirts, women's underwear, items for the home.

En mi comunidad me conocen con el nombre de Melissa, me dedico a la venta de ropa para niño, dama y caballero, asi como articulos para el hogar por encargos. Tengo 5 años de vender de manera ambulante lo que me permitio hacerme una clientela fija, que me prefieren por los precios bajos que les doy en la mercaderia. Los ingresos que obtengo me ayudan con los gastos de mi familia y los estudios de mis hijos.

loans.use: Compra de camisas para niño, ropa interior para mujer, y articulos para el hogar

loans.name: Marlon Antonio

texts.en:
I am known as Don Antonio and my work is detailing covers for car seats. I have had my business for eight years and it is located in the corner of my home. My sales have increased because of the prices and quality of my seat covers. Thanks to my earnings I am able to feed my family and to help my son in his studies. My primary goal now is to sell more so that I can send my son to University.

Loan Use: Purchase of fabric, thread, plastics, and decorative pieces.

Me conocen como don Antonio y me dedico a la elaboracion de cobertores para asientos de carros, tengo ocho años de tener mi negocio ubicado en una esquina de mi residencia. Mis ventas han aumentado por los precios y calidad de mis cobertores. Gracias a los ingresos que tengo de mi negocio puedo ayudar a mi familia en su alimentacion y estudios de mi hijo, y mi mayor reto ahora es vender mas para poder enviarlo a la universidad.

loans.use: Compra de tela, hilo, plasticos y articulos decorativos

loans.name: Orfilia Regina

texts.en:
Everyone knows me as Dona Orfi, and my little cakes are one of the sweets most sold at my store. I also sell tamales with beans, baleadas (honduran specialty) and sodas. I have had my business for five years and I have been able to earn enough to send my two sons through university. My cakes are famous and people come from other neighborhoods to buy them.

Loan Use: Purchase of cornflour, rice, butter, salt, spices and other items.

Todos me conocen por doña Orfi, y mis pastelitos son uno de las golosinas mas vendidas en mi negocio, tambien vendo tamalitos con frijoles, baleadas, refrescos naturales. Tengo 5 años de tener mi negocio y hasta este momento he logrado graduar a mis dos hijos en la universidad. Mis pastelitos son famosos y otras personas vienen a mi colonia a comprarlos.

loans.use: Compra de harina de maiz, arroz, manteca, sal, especias y otros

loans.name: Saturnina

texts.en:
My name is Saturnina, but I am known as Nina, I work making and selling soft corncob tamales, which is a food typical of our country, I have been selling these for five years, and are particularly delicious when served with butter. I also make fried elote (soft corncob) and roasted elote. Thanks to my income I am able to send money to my son and to make some improvements in my daily living.

Loan Use: Purchase elotes ( tender corncob, firewood, milk, margarine, and other items.

Mi nombre es Saturnina, pero me conocen como Nina, me dedico a la elaboracion y venta de tamalitos de elote que es una comida tipica en nuestro pais, tengo cinco años de vender este producto que son deliciosos, especialmente cuando se acompañan con mantequilla. Tambien hago fritas de elote y elote asado. Gracias a los ingresos que he podido percibir en mis ventas he logrado sacar adelante a mi hijo y hacerle algunas mejores a mi vivienda.

loans.use: Compra de elotes, leña, leche, margarina y otros

loans.name: Yemin Orfilia

texts.en:
I have had my business for several years, in which I sell used shoes, women's accessories, underwear, lotions and other items. With my earnings, I help my children in their studies and my own. I need to stock my inventory in order to better my sales and to help with the family expenses.

Loan Use: Purchase shoes for women and children, lotions, accessories.

Tengo mi negocio desde hace algunos años, en el que vendo zapatos usados, accesorios para dama, ropa interior, lociones y otros. Con las ganancias de mi negocio he ayudado a mis hijos en sus estudios y los mios propios. Necesito abastecer mi inventario para poder obtener mejores ganancias y ayudar con los gastos familiares.

loans.use: Compra de zapatos para niño y dama, lociones y accesorios.

loans.name: Alma Yanira

texts.en:
My name is Alma and I tailor and sell clothes for children, bed clothing, and underwear for children and adults. The majority of my sales are made to order and others are tailoring and the people who visit my business then buy them. My business has grown due to the good quality of my work and the prices. I have one son who is 12 years old, who will enter the sixth grade this year, and I hope to help him continue with his studies.

Loan Use: Purchase blouses, skirts, underwear, and for the making of clothing items.

Me llamo Alma y me dedico a la confeccion y venta de ropa para niño, ropa de cama, ropa interior de niño y adulto. La mayoria de mis ventas son por encargo, y otra que confecciona y las personas que visitan mi negocio las compran. Mi negocio ha crecido debido al buen trabajo que elaboro y precios, a mis clientes les gusta el acabado de sus prendas. Tengo un hijo de 12 años que este año sale de su sexto grado y espero poder ayudarle para que continue en sus estudios.

loans.use: Compra de camisas, faltas, ropa interior, asi como la elaboracion de prendas de vestir.

loans.name: Benita Obex

texts.en:
I have had my business for five years, which is making tortillas, I began as an employee to learn the trade and I had the opportunity to start my own business. I have three children, who help me in their spare time, and now I have two employees, who help me meet the demand from restaurants and household women who prefer my tortillas, for their good taste.

Loan Use: Purchase corn, firewood, lime and other items.

Tengo cinco años de tener mi negocio en la elaboracion de tortillas, comence como empleada a conocer el negocio y tuve la oportunidad de trabajar para tener el mio propio. Tengo tres hijos que me han ayudado en sus ratos libres, ahora tengo dos empleadas que me ayudan a suplir la demanda de los restaurantes y amas de casa que prefieren mis tortillas por su buen sabor.

loans.use: Compra de maiz, leña, cal, y otros.

loans.name: Hector David

texts.en:
My name is Hector David M., and I sell clothes, shoes and other items accessories for children and adults. I have had my business for three years and has grown and with what I earn, I can help my children in their studies and my desire is to increase my earnings so that they can go to University and to become hard working, professional people who will help our country in the future.

Loan Use: Purchase clothes and shoes for children and adults.

Me llamo Hector David M., me dedico a la venta de ropa, zapatos y otros accesorios para niño y adulto. Tengo tres años de tener mi negocio que ha crecido y con lo que me genera en ganacias he podido ayudar a mis hijos en sus estudios y mi deseo es obtener mejores ingresos para que puedan ir a la universidad y llegar a ser buenas personas trabajadores y profesionales que ayuden a nuestro pais a salir adelante.

loans.use: Compra de ropa y calzado para niño y adulto

loans.name: Jose Luis

texts.en:
My name is Jose Luis, in my neighborhood, I am known for having problems walking and I use crutches. On account of my physical condition, I could not find work in any business. So I decided to sell candies on the side of one of the boulevards of the city Comayaguela. I need to supply my business to increase my earnings and so that I can help my family in their food and school costs of my children.

Loan Use: Purchas of juices, churros, candies, chiclets and other items.

Me llamo Jose Luis, en mi colonia me conocen ya que tengo problemas para caminar uso muletas, por mi incapacidad fisica, por no tener empleo en ninguna institucion decidi vender dulces a la orilla de uno de los boulevares de la ciudad de Comayaguela. Necesito surtir mi negocio para incrementar mis ingresos y poder ayudar a mi famiia en sus gastos de alimentacion y estudios de mis hijos.

loans.use: Compra de jugos, churros, confites, chiclets y otros

loans.name: Karla Patricia

texts.en:
I sell second hand bed clothes, women's accessories, perfumes and other items. I have had my street vending business for two years, with which I have been able to continue studying and to help my parents, who are very humble people, of little resources. I would like to increase my sales and to sell a variety of items in my business.

Loan Use: Purchase bed-clothes, women's accessories, and other items.

Me dedico a la venta de ropa usada de cama, accesorios para dama, perfumes y otros. Tengo dos años de tener mi negocio ambulante, con lo que he podido seguir estudiando y ayudar a mis padres que son personas humildes y de bajos recursos. Me gustaria poder incrementar mis ventas y veder variedad de articulos en mi negocio.

loans.use: Venta de ropa de cama, accesorios de dama y otros.

loans.name: Lourdes Patricia

texts.en:
My name is Lourdes B., and I have had my pulperia(restaurant/market) for six years, it is located in one of the largest commuter zones in my city, which is a stop for buses and taxis. My sales have increased and I need to supply my business in order to offer a variety of products like rice, beans, milk, eggs, bread and other items, which are the most sold, to offer my clients what they need.

Loan Use: Purchase confections, milk, bread, sodas, rice, beans, sugar, butter, coffee, and other items.

Me llamo Lourdes B., tengo una pulperia desde hace seis años, esta ubicada en una de las zonas de mayor transito en la ciudad ya que es parada de buses y taxis. Mis ventas han aumentado y necesito abastecer mi negocio para ofrecer variedad de producto de consumo como arroz, frijoles, leche, huevos, pan y otros que son los mas vendidos y de esta manera brindarles a mis clientes lo que ellos necesitan.

loans.use: Compra de confites, leche, pan, refrescos, arroz, frijoles, azucar, manteca, cafe y otros.

loans.name: Maria De La Luz

texts.en:
My name is Maria de la Luz and I have been selling new and used shoes for five years. My income has enabled my to help with family expenses and the education of my children.

Loan Use: Purchase new and used shoes.

Me llamo Maria de la Luz, y me dedico a la venta de zapatos nuevos y usados desde hace cinco años. Los ingresos que he obtenido de mi negocio me han ayudado con los gastos familiares y la educacion de mis hijos.

loans.use: Compra de zapatos nuevos y usados

loans.name: Martha Liliana

texts.en:
My name is Martha, but everyone knows me as Martita, I sell cometics, wallets, sashes and other items.I have had my business for five years and it has grown with my sales. Now I need to supply my business to support my children in their studies.

Use of Loan: Purchas of cosmetics, wallets, sashes, electronic devices and other items.

Me llamo Martha pero todos me conocen por Martita, vendo cosmeticos, carteras, fajas y otros. Mi negocio lo tengo desde hace cinco años el que ha crecido al igual que mis ventas, en este momento necesito abastecer el negocio para apoyar a mis hijos en sus estudios.

loans.use: Compra de cosmeticos, carteras, fajas, aparatos electricos y otros.

loans.name: Teodoro

texts.en: Teodoro B. was born in Quevado, Ecuador and has lived in Guayaquil for nearly fifteen years now. He is married with five children and owns a small auto mechanic shop called Taller Mecánico B.. Teodoro rents a shop in an area called La Zona and would like to own this building someday. When he first started out as an apprentice mechanic in another shop, he always dreamed of growing his business to be one of the biggest in Guayaquil. His hours are 9am until 7pm Monday through Saturday. Mr. B. is requesting a $950 loan to be able to purchase materials most often used in the day-today management of his repair shop. Specifically, he needs to buy engine compressors, gauges, hoses, pumps, and a heavy duty set of power tools. Teodoro want prospective lenders to know that he has a specific plan for reaching out to new clients and intends on growing his business two-fold over the next year.

loans.use: Specifically, he needs to buy engine compressors, gauges, hoses, pumps, and a heavy duty set of power tools.

loans.name: Juan

texts.en: Juan Q. was born in Vinces, Ecuador. He is a forty-year-old married man who also owns a small restaurant. His cooks up specialties like encebollado and lunch dishes like seco de pollo (chicken stew with rice) and lomo salteado (thinly cut beef with onions and tomatoes). Encebollado is a favorite in Ecuador because of the incredible mix of ingredients, including albacore tuna, onions, yucca, and lime, but also because of its hangover-curing powers. Juan works every day from 6am until 3pm, serving local clients who stop in for a hearty lunch. He is asking for this $800 microloan, so that he can purchase cooking items like spices and utensils. Also, Mr. Q. wants to be free of the “chulqueros” or loan sharks who generally charge 20% monthly. Juan wants potential lenders to know that he is very hard-working and entrepreneurial. He recognizes the opportunity in front of him and has agreed to pay back his loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: He is asking for this $800 microloan, so that he can purchase cooking items like spices and utensils.

loans.name: Sikinanene

texts.en: Sikinanene is 48 years of age, married and has five children. She has two girls and three boys and all go to school. Her two daughters are in college and the two boys are in secondary school. Sikananene started her business 15 years ago; she has managed to educate her children up to college all by the support from the small business. She sells items made out of beads such as necklaces, belts, bags and bracelets. In addition to this, she sells steers but these do not have a constant cash flow this is why she supplements it with bead work.

loans.use: Asai wants to buy six steers to be grazed for at least six month and then be sold one by one.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace was born 49 years ago. She is married and the couple is blessed with six children. She was not lucky to joining secondary school like others but fortunately she finished primary school and thus, she knows how to read and write most words.
She owns a stone quarry where she gets blocks used for building residential and commercial houses. She sells these blocks in Kiserian, Kajiado and Isinya Town. Transportation of blocks is difficult when you are hiring than using your own lorry. Grace works hard such that in two years she is able to buy her own Lorry.

loans.use: Grace wants to increase the supply of building blocks by hiring at least two Lorries.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 62 years old. She is a window with 5 grown up children. Mary was amongst the first people who settled in Kware, Rongai. A staunch Catholic, Mary and a few Catholic faithful rented a room in Kware where they were holding their prayers and Sunday service.

For many years has been actively involved in preaching the word of God. Mary has seen the congregation of St Mary’s Catholic Church grow from very few faithful members to the large congregation to date. Mary is a serious and hard working lady. She started by growing and selling maize, beans, potatoes, peas and vegetables. From this small business, she saved and bought a small plot of land in Kandisi. As years went by, she specialized in growing maize and beans which are seasonal, and vegetables for her daily income.

Mary decided to move her family to Kandisi, a residential area near Rongai after she had built a semi-permanent house. She then built 6 semi-permanent rooms in Kware in a plot she had bought when she was staying there and rented them out at USD 4 per month. The income from these rooms enabled her to buy a cow. The reason she decided to buy a cow was that many people wanted milk but it was little in the area and expensive. She now has three dairy cows and at least she gets 40 litres per day. She sells 37 litres and lives 3 litres for her family. She gets USD 15 per day from the sale of milk and USD 5 from vegetables.

Recently the Olkejuado County Council demarcated Kware plots and gave title deeds to the old residents. Mary was lucky to have been allocated one. Mary plans to start by upgrading 4 rooms and to have the construction done within one month. After renovation, she will rent them at USD 15. Mary’s future plan is to install electricity and water to make life easy for her tenants.

loans.use: Mary wants to renovate her rental rooms. She will use the loan to buy sand, cement, Iron sheets, nails and pebbles.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is a 50 year old Masaai lady; she is married and has 6 children. Betty being a member of Enkiramat Women group is one of the members who received training that was done by WEEC.

She has improved her relationship with her customers honouring her promises on time and the community as well. She has benefited from the group revolving fund by accessing two loans and she has been encouraged to save every month. She is able to save USD 2 per month and she paid back her loans in time. The small loans have enabled her to buy beads and the leather she uses to make her bead decorations.

Betty sells her bead items to people in Isinya and Kitengela market every week days whereas on Saturdays, she takes her items to Maasai Market in Nairobi. Maasai market is her strong hold where she takes her decorations Wednesdays and Saturdays. Her outstanding creativity has made her clientele base to grow steadily. She needs a loan of USD 450 to buy materials for her beadwork to cover all the orders she received at the beginning of this month.

loans.use: Betty wants to buy beads, leather materials for making bags and belts.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is 26 years old; she is married with 3 children. Agnes completed her secondary school education and this assists her being a secretary of Inkiramat women group. She maintains proper and accurate records of the group and this helps in operating the revolving fund. Agnes’ main economic activity is buying and selling of steers. She runs her business with her husband which is not common in the Maaai culture. However, they are not against the culture but believe culture should embrace the wellbeing of people.  Agnes is good in selecting small steers for fattening and this has given her an edge over other traders because at the end of 4 months she starts selling and selling quality steers. The land available can raise over 30 cows and this why she intends to use this opportunity to increase the number of steers. With a loan of USD 450, Agnes will be able to buy 4 medium size Steers. She will sell them after 4 months at more than double the price. Agnes also foresees a better market in future whereby the market prices will be steady. She feels that if current developments recorded in the livestock sector continue, she will work hard to meet her target of increasing the Steers to 40 in a very short time.

loans.use: Agnes wants to buy 4 medium size steers

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary was born 41 years ago in Empuyiankat, Kajiado. As young girl she used to look after her fathers cattle and did not get a chance of attending school. However, her wish is to educate her five children to sail through the tabulate waters of this world. Two of her children are in college while the rest are in secondary school. She is married to a responsible man who contributes towards the development of their family. Mary is a strong member of Inkiramat women group. She sells bead items and milk to earn a living. She sells milk to hotels at Kitengela town and bead items in Isinya as well as Kiserian. Mary’s group is scheduled for training in livestock management towards the end of September and this aims at equipping members with new methods of livestock management to prepare them for the new business they are to start. She wants to start a business of rearing steers and selling them after some time. She wants to utilize the expanding market and the availability of pasture in the area at present. Mary plans to start with 2 small steers and later will develop the capacity to raise about 10 steers. At this level, she will be in a position to providing for her family the minimum necessities of life.

loans.use: Mary wants to buy 2 small steers.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is 50 years old. She is married and has 7 children. Her children have grown up, five are working while two are in college. She is a member of Anglican Church of Kenya. She is the secretary of the mothers union in her church. Nancy is a member of Kenyanjeru starlight women group. She has been a member of this group since its formation and has attended many trainings. Nancy’s main economic activity is farming. She has a small plot of land where she grows maize, beans and tea. One portion is paddocked for grazing her dairy cow. Nancy receives some monthly income from the sale Tea and milk. The rest of the land is used to grow Nippier grass for her cow and food crops for her family. She intercrops maize, beans, potatoes and vegetables because of shortage of land. On every market day Nancy sells Kales and green maize at the local Gakira market.                                                                                                        
Nancy wants to start growing Fruits, Georgettes and pepper. She wants to prepare a portion of her plot for growing of the new crops. She intends to use organic fertilizer in this project enhance its productivity. She will also buy quality seeds from well known dealers. She is targeting to sell much of her products at the Ngara market in Nairobi because the demand for these products is high in Nairobi city. After the take off of this project, Nancy will be able to increase her income and this will push her at the foot steps of the income ladder. This will enable her to cater for her household expenses and pay up her loan without much strain.

loans.use: Nancy would like to buy hybrid seeds for pepper and georgettes to increase productivity.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is 40 years old. She is married and has 6 children. Eunice is a member of the Anglican Church of Kenya and Kenyanjeru Starlight women group. The reason for joining this group was get a way of accessing loans to help her find solutions to her financial challenges.  It was/is difficult to get a loan without being a member of a CBO especially if you have no collateral. She has accessed group loans twice and was able to pay promptly.
Eunice’s main economic activity is buying fruits in bulk and selling to fruit vendors in town mainly Githurai market. Her customers come from as far as Baba Ndogo, Kasarani, Mwiki and Korokocho. Eunice is a reliable supplier and this has made her business grow in terms of customers and profits. She checks on her main customers frequently and takes orders before she goes to the villages to buy the produce. This ensures that she sells most of her products within a day or two. While in the market, she lists the products that are highly demanded and tries to identify areas where to get them. Eunice’ business operates on a cash basis and therefore has to maintain a reasonable amount of cash to run the business smoothly. Massive cash withdrawals from her business would make her fail to serve all her customers, the profits will shrink and eventually it might lead to business closure.

loans.use: Eunice requires a loan of USD 150 to pay school fees for her child. She will in turn repay the loan every month.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en: At 64, Nancy believes that she has not yet reached a point in life to give up working. Her 6 children are all independent but she takes care of 2 of her grandsons who give her company. These two grandsons are in primary and she is responsible for all the necessities. She joined WEEC and Kenyanjeru Women’s group 5 years ago and this has helped her in various ways. She was able to get a diary cow which she got as a loan in 2005, it’s fully paid up and she drinks milk as she wants while the balance is sold. She sells 5 litres a day giving her $42 per month. She saves this money to take care of her grandsons. She has tea and coffee not on a large scale but still gives her some $ 50 per month. She also grows beans and maize but they are seasonal. She hopes to increase output when she plants hybrid seeds and the main objective is to accumulate enough money to buy another dairy cow. With milk she will not go wrong because there is ready market because of the revival of Kenya cooperative creameries. Her grandsons will be assured of good education and to herself; she will enjoy her old age.

loans.use: Nancy wants to buy hybrid maize seeds and a water tank

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily was born 42 years ago. She is married to a wonderful husband and they are blessed with 2 children. She is a committed member of Kenyanjeru Starlight and it has assisted her to access loans and save some money. Emily had put most of her land to cultivating coffee and a small portion was left for growing the family’s food crops. Emily had this to say about the coffee market “For several years the market situation in the coffee industry has been so…..low not improving at all it’s quite discouraging. The income I have been receiving from the sale of coffee has been the same…VERY LOW!”  For years life has been quite challenging, however, she managed to educate her two children who are yet to join High School.
Since 2004, Emily has been surviving on loans from her group and she set up a retail shop at Gacharageieni shopping centre and its doing very well. Emily’s daily sales are between USD 115 – 160 and she says there is an opportunity for business growth. The sales are highest towards the end of the month and also during the market days. Emily would like to increase the sales by adding stock of those goods that go very fast such as rice and wheat flour.

loans.use: This loan will help her buy rice and wheat flour to have the right stock to counter the high demand.

loans.name: Sonia Maribel

texts.en:
The drink Pinol is typical to my country, you can drink it cold or hot, according to taste. I have had my small business, making pinoles, for five years. I sell the drinks to clients, pulperias(small restaurants) and to people outside of the capital. I have one son who I help with his studies and expenses. I am a single mother and I have to seek a way to give us a better way of life.

Loan Use: Purchase corn, chocolate, cacao, cinnamon.

El pinol es una bebida tipica en nuestro pais, puede tomarse helada o caliente segun el gusto de cada persona, tengo cinco años de tener mi pequeña fabrica de pinoles que vendo a clientes, pulperias y personas de afuera de la capital. Tengo 1 hijo al que he ayudado con sus estudios y gastos, ya que soy madre soltera tengo que buscar la manera de darnos una manera mejor de vivir.

loans.use: Compra de maiz, chocolate, cacao, canela

loans.name: Yessenia Jacqueline

texts.en:
My name is Yessenia V. and I sell shoes, clothes, wallets, perfumes and other items. I have had my business for two years, which helps me settle my family's expenses and studies. Now, by demand of sales, I have to increase my inventory and buy new products, and through which, better our level of living.

Loan Use: Purchase clothes, shoes for children and adults.

Me llamo Yessenia V. y me dedico a la venta de zapatos, ropa, carteras, perfumes y otros. Tengo dos años de tener mi negocio que me ayuda a solventar mis gastos familiares, estudios. En este momento y por la demanda de las ventas que tengo necesito incrementar mi inventario y comprar nuevos productos y de esta manera mejorar nuestro nivel de vida.

loans.use: Compra de ropa, zapatos para niño y adulto.

loans.name: Anny

texts.en:
My name is Anny and I sell clothes for adults and for children, I have had my business for five years, with which I have been able to care for my two children who are school-aged. I make my sales by commission, I visit offices and neighbors who buy what they need from me, and commission me to sell them other items.

Loan Use: Purchase blouses, pants, T-shirts, socks, shorts, for adults and children.

Me llamo Anny y me dedico a la venta de ropa para adulto y niño, tengo cinco años de tener mi negocio con el que he logrado mantener a mis dos hijos que estan en edad escolar. Mis ventas las hago por encargo, visito oficinas y vecinos quienes me comprar lo que necesitan y me hacen encargos de otros productos.

loans.use: Compra de camisas, pantalones, camisetas, calcetines, short, para adulto y niño.

loans.name: Gloria Estela

texts.en:
My name is Gloria Estela and I have been working with the detailing and selling of bed clothing for five years. I have many clients who have their own stores who ask me for bedsheets, pillowcases, and cushions for their clients. Thanks to my good work and my prices I have been able to continue to sell and support my children with their studies. Now, I need materials to embrioder a large order that I have been commissioned.

Loan Use: Purchase of fabric, thread, laces, decorative ribbon and other items.

Me llamo Gloria Estela y me dedico a la elaboracion y venta de ropa de cama desde hace 5 años. Tengo muchos clientes de tiendas que me hacen pedidos de cameras, sobrefundas, cojines para sus clientes, gracias al buen trabajo y precios que tengo he podido vender y apoyar a mis hijos en sus estudios. En este momento necesito materiales para poder elaborar un pedido grande que tengo por encargo.

loans.use: Compra de tela, hilos, encajes, cinta decorativa y otros.

loans.name: Hilda Margarita

texts.en:
My name is Hilda Margarite H., I have had my pulperia(restaurant/market)for four years, it is well loacted and I need to supply my business with a variety of fresh products in order to offer good products and service to my clients. This is a family business and my children help me in the store in their spare time.

Loan Use:Purchase milk, sodas, bread, dairy products, margarine, and other items.

Mi nombre es Hilda Margarita H., tengo una pulperia desde hace cuatro años, esta bien ubicada y necesito surtir mi negocio con producto fresco y variado para brindar buenos productos y servicio a mis clientes. Este es un negocio familiar y mis hijos me ayudan a vender en sus momentos libres.

loans.use: Compra de leche, refrescos, pan, lacteos, margarina y otros

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
I have been making and selling tortillas for five years. I have two schoole aged sons, who help me deliver tortillas to my clients after they return from school. My sales have increased and I have not been able to keep up because I do not have enough disposable income to buy more corn and firewood. I hope to increase our earnings and give us a better standard of living.

Loan Use: Purchase corn, firewood, lime.

Me dedico a la fabricacion y venta de tortillas, tengo cinco años de tener mis ventas. Tengo dos hijos en edad escolar y me ayudan a entrar a mis clientes sus tortillas despues que regresan de la escuela. Las ventas han aumentado y no he podido cubrir ya que no cuento con sufieciente capital de trabajo para comprar maiz y la leña. Espero poder obtener mas ingresos y que tengamos un mejor nivel de vida.

loans.use: Compra de Maiz, lena, cal.

payments.comment: Mis ventas de tortillas aumentaron ya que pude atender mas personas, ahora necesito mas para incrementar mis ventas un poco mas, gracias por ayuda.

loans.name: Sotera Yamileth

texts.en:
My name is Yamileth, I live in the city of Danli and I sell craftworks and cosmetics as a street merchant, working on commission. The earnings I make from my sales help me with family expenses and with the studies of my three brothers, since our mother passed away some years ago, leaving me to care for them. My brothers help me sell my items as it is our only form of income for now.

Loan Use: Purchase of handicrafts and cosmetics

Me llamo Yamileth, vivo en la ciudad de Danli y me dedico a la venta de artesanias y cosmeticos de manera ambulante y por encargo, los ingresos que percibo de mis ventas me ayudan con el gasto familiar y con los estudios de mis 3 hermanos ya que hace algunos años nuestra madre murio y yo me hice cargo de ellos. Mis hermanos me ayudan a vender ya que es nuestro unico ingreso en este momento.

loans.use: Compra de Artesanias, cosmeticos

loans.name: Martha Gladys

texts.en:
I have been working for five years in my small business, which is located in my home and is half a block from the Social Security building of out town. At the moment, I need to expand my business so that my daughter, who is in her final year of high school, can go to university to continue with her studies. The earnings I make help me with family expenses.

Loan Use: Purchase bonbons, chiclets, confections, churros, sodas and other items.

Tengo cinco años de tener mi pequeño negocio que esta ubicado en mi casa de habitacion y a media cuadra del Seguro Social de nuestra ciudad. En este momento necesito ampliar mi negocio ya que mi hija esta en su ultimo año de estudios secundarios y mi meta es enviarla a la universidad para que continue sus estudios. Los ingresos que percibo actualmente me ayudan con los gastos familiares.

loans.use: Compra de bombones, chiclets, confites, churros, refrescos y otros

loans.name: Reina Cleotilde

texts.en:
My name is Reina and everyone knows me for the delicious bread that I make. I have had my bread business for five years, and some people allow me to sell my bread in their pulperias (small restaurant/markets), businesses and pharmacies. I also recycle paper to make craft-paper, that I also sell in stationary stores. The earnings I make help my mother, who is old and needs to be cared for.

Loan Use: Purchase flour, butter, cinnamon, sugar, tins, and other items.

Me llamo Reina y todos me conocen por el delicioso pan que elaboro, tengo cinco años de tener mi negocio de pan y algunas personas me han permitido venderlos en sus pulperias, negocios, farmacias. Tambien trabajo en el reciclaje para hacer papel artesanal que tambien lo vendo a papelerias. Los ingresos que percibo me ayudan con los gastos familiares y poder ayudar a mi madre que es una ancianita y necesita de mis cuidados.

loans.use: Compra de harina, manteca, canela, azucar, sal, moldes y otros.

loans.name: Rene Adolfo

texts.en:
I am a merchant, I have a small stand in the center of the city, from which I sell sweets, candies, and CDs. With my earnings, I have been able to help my mother who is now a single mother, I help her when I am able to, and now that she is aging, she needs me.

Loan Use: Purchase sweets, churros, CDs and other items.

Soy comerciante, tengo una pequeña carreta en el centro de la ciudad en la que vendo dulces, golosinas y CDs. Con los ingresos que percibo he podido ayudar a mi madre ya que como madre soltera me ayudo cuando pudo y ahora de anciana necesita de mi. Mi idea es poder comprar mas Cds y otro producto variado para mejorar mis ingresos.

loans.use: Compra de dulces, churros, CD, y otros.

loans.name: Sandra Raquel

texts.en:
My name is Sandra Marinez and I have been selling underwear on Mayoreo Street, which is the main market of our city. I am a single mother, I have three children who are able to study thanks to my earnings. Now, I need to supply my business with new products since our city is visited by many people from surrounding villages and who buy items from my business.

Loan Use: Purchase underwear for children and adults.

Mi nombre es Sandra M., me dedico a la venta de ropa interior en la calle del mayoreo que es el mercado de nuestra ciudad. Soy madre soltera, tengo 3 hijos que estudian gracias a las ganacias que obtengo de mis ventas. En este momento necesito surtir mi negocio con producto nuevo ya que ahora nuestra ciudad es bastante visitada por otras personas de aldeas cercanas y compran en mi negocio.

loans.use: Compra de ropa interior de adulto y niño

loans.name: Maria De Los Angeles

texts.en:
ENGLISH

Maria de los Angeles F. M. is 47 years old, she is married and has five children. She has a small business, where she sells different meals and snacks. She started her business five years ago, because she needed to help the family economy, her husband is a construction worker and their income is very variable. At the beginning she just sold corn and tamales but now she has diversified and has a complete menu with several options of meals. She has a mobile kiosk where she works with two more people, one of them is her daughter.

Mrs. F. is requesting a loan for $1,100 USD to pay back in a term of 6-12 months. This will be to buy a new stove because the one that she has is not convenient to offer a good and quick service to their clients.

SPANISH

La señora Maria de los Angeles F. M. tiene 47 años esta casada y tiene 5 hijos . Tiene un negocio de venta de comida que inicio hace mas de cinco años ante la necesidad de ayudar al ingreso familiar, ya que su esposo es trabajador de la construcción y sus ingresos son muy variables. Al principio solo vendía elotes y tamales, pero con el tiempo diversifico sus productos y actualmente vende comidas, cuenta con un puesto semi-fijo, el cual atiende ella misma y brinda trabajo a dos personas, una de ellas su hija. La Señora Angeles solicita un crédito por $1,100 USD a pagar en un plazo de siete meses, para comprar una nueva estufa, ya que la que tiene es insuficiente para brindar el servicio rápido a sus clientes.

loans.use: Buy a new stove

loans.name: Ramón

texts.en:
ENGLISH

Ramon started his business 14 years ago, selling fruits and vegetables to his neighbors in his house. He carries his products on his truck and offers them to different towns around his home. He is married and has four children, his wife helps him to sell at home.

Mr. C. wants to develop his business, that is why three months ago he built a special cold room where he can keep his products better, now he needs working capital and therefore he is requesting a loan for $925 USD. He offers to repay in 6 months. With this loan he will be able to act as a wholesaler and get better prices, bringing welfare to his family.

ESPAÑOL

Ramón Tiene 14 años con su negocio de venta de frutas y verduras, vende en su casa a sus vecinos y también en las calles y en algunos pueblos cercanos, usando una camioneta en donde transporta sus productos. Esta casado y tiene cuatro hijos, su esposa le ayuda ocupándose de la venta en su casa.

El Sr. C. quiere hacer crecer su negocio y es por eso que construyo un pequeño cuarto frío en su casa para guardar las frutas y verduras, pero por esta inversión ahora requiere de capital de trabajo y es por eso que solicita el crédito por $925 USD a pagar en 6 meses, para poder comprar en mayores cantidades a precios mas bajos y aumentar sus utilidades y así beneficiar a su familia .

loans.use: Fruits and Vegetables

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase on the Capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To improve on stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For completion of building

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To improve on stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase on his capital

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
ENGLISH

Three years ago Julia started a business offering shoes by catalogue. She wanted to support the family economy because her husband is a taxi driver and his income is not steady or enough to meet the families needs (i.e. such as the school expenses for their children). The family members are: Julia, her husband and their five children. She sells her merchandise giving credit or through “tandas” (by turn). With the new school period approaching, she requires this credit and with this amount she will be able to finance her clients in this upcoming season.

She is requesting a loan for $650.00 USD, payable in a term of 4-8 months. She wants to buy enough merchandise and in this way to face the increase of her clients demand for this season.

ESPAÑOL

Hace 3 años que la Sra. Julia inicio su negocio de venta de zapatos por catálogo a fin de ayudar a su economía familiar, ya que su esposo es chofer de un taxi y sus ingresos son variables y no podían cubrir las necesidades de educación de sus hijos. Su familia esta formada por ella, su esposo y tienen 5 hijos. La forma en que vende sus productos es a crédito o mediante tandas. Es por eso que en esta temporada escolar en que los niños regresan a clases requiere de un préstamo para poder financiar a sus clientes.

El préstamo que solicita Julia es de $650 USD a pagar en un plazo de 4-8 meses, el cual le permitirá comprar suficientes mercancías para hacer frente al incremento en la demanda de sus clientes para esta temporada.

loans.use: Merchandise

loans.name: Juana

texts.en:
ENGLISH

Mrs. Juana is a 54 year old woman. She has had a Stationary and Gifts Store for 20 years. This began when her husband was fired from where he used to work, and with the settlement they decided to start a small business as a unique source of income to cover the necessities of their children.

She offers scholastic products and gifts, but she realizes more of these gifts would let her obtain higher gains. She is requesting a loan of $925 USD to pay back in a period of 3-6 months. And with this loan, she wishes to buy more scholastic articles and gifts. She will take advantage of the back to school season, as it is one of the best seasons of the year for her business.

ESPAÑOL

La señora Juana es una mujer de 54 años que tiene un negocio de Papelería, Mercería y Venta de regalos el cual inició hace 20 años, debido a que su esposo fue despedido de donde trabajaba y con el dinero que le dieron pusieron su pequeño negocio como única fuente de ingresos para poder cubrir las necesidades de sus tres hijos.

En su negocio ofrece productos escolares y de mercería, aunque confiesa que la venta de regalos es la que deja mayores ganancias. Esta solicitando un crédito por $925 USD a pagar en un período de 3-6 meses, para comprar artículos escolares y regalos y poder aprovechar la temporada escolar que inicia y que trae consigo altas ventas.

loans.use: Merchandise

loans.name: Maria Guadalupe

texts.en:
ENGLISH

17 years ago Maria Guadalupe G. and her husband started a small business where they sell motor oil and spare parts. With the support of her husband and their children, the business has been growing and now it is the unique source of the family income.

Lupita is requesting a loan of $925 USD and she offers to pay back in 6-12 months. This loan will be used to purchase more merchandise to sell in their store. She knows the key of success is to supply a great variety of products and when their clients visit her store, they will find what they need at a good price. With the loan she plans to buy as a wholesaler, diminishing their cost. And then she will offer her merchandise at better prices and consequently, she will obtain the preference of their clients.

ESPAÑOL

Desde hace 17 años María Guadalupe G. y su esposo iniciaron un pequeño negocio de venta de lubricantes y refacciones para automóviles. Con la ayuda de su esposo y sus hijos han hecho crecer el negocio, el cual es la única fuente de ingresos de la familia.

Lupita esta solicitando un crédito por $925 USD para surtir de mercancía su negocio, ya que sabe que la clave de su éxito es tener de todo un poco para que cuando el cliente llegue, encuentre lo que necesita y a un buen precio. Es por eso que con el préstamo podrá comprar en mayor volumen, reduciendo sus costos y podrá ofrecer sus productos a mejores precios, consiguiendo de esta forma la preferencia de sus clientes.

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: “Vicky” Virginia

texts.en:
ENGLISH

Vicky was born in Soto La Marina, a port in front of The Mexican Gulf. She's lived there since 1984, and then she moved to Cadereyta. She got divorced a long time ago and she started a small grocery store. Now she has been growing and offering frozen sea food and fish.

Mrs. A. is requesting a loan of $1,200 USD to repay in a term of 6-12 months. She wishes to buy a new freezer with more capacity to store foods than the one that she currently has. This is because the demand has been increasing lately and she wants to continue offering an excellent service to her clients.

ESPAÑOL

La señora Virginia nació en Soto La Marina, un puerto que esta en frente del Golfo de México, y desde 1984 se mudó a Cadereyta. Ella se divorció hace mucho tiempo y por lo mismo tuvo necesidad de empezar su negocio, que al principio solo era de abarrotes, pero con el tiempo ha logrado ampliar sus actividades ofreciendo ahora pescados y mariscos congelados.

La Sra. A. esta solicitando un préstamo por $1,200 USD a pagar en un plazo de 6-12 meses, para comprar un congelador de mayor capacidad al que tiene, pues como se ha incrementado la demanda por sus productos ella quiere seguir brindando un excelente servicio a sus clientes, ofreciéndoles productos de calidad.

loans.use: To buy a new freezer

loans.name: Antero

texts.en:
ENGLISH

Mr. Antero Medellin has to work hard to supply the needs of his family. He practices different activities: he rents a taxicab several hours by day, and he sells clothes, cheese and cookies in some fleet markets. He is married and has three children. His wife supports him and helps him to sell clothes and cookies.

He is requesting a loan for $475 USD, to pay back in 6-12 months. He needs to supply clothes for the next season and raw materials for cookies, because in autumn time there is a large increase in demand for both.

ESPAÑOL

Ante la necesidad de sacar adelante a su familia el Señor Antero M. realiza diversas actividades como fuente de ingreso, entre las cuales podemos mencionar que renta un taxi varias horas al día, y vende ropa y galletas en algunos mercados rodantes en donde le permiten ofrecer sus productos. El esta casado y tiene tres hijos, para la venta de ropa y galletas le ayudan su esposa y su hija.

Esta requiriendo un crédito por $475 USD a pagar en 6-12 meses, para comprar ropa para la próxima temporada, además de poder surtir de materias primas para la elaboración de galletas, para aprovechar que con el otoño la gente solicita mas sus galletas.

loans.use: clothes and raw materials

loans.name: Luz Leticia

texts.en:
ENGLISH

Leticia is a young woman, she works hard every day. Three years ago she started a stationary store. She is married and has four children. Leticia's husband has to work outside the city and for this reason she handles her business by herself. She started her business because she wanted to offer a better future for her family.

She is requesting a loan for $475 USD to pay in a term of 5-10 months, she wants to supply merchandise and offer a better stock to the clients now as they enter school season.

ESPAÑOL

La Señora Leticia es una mujer joven muy trabajadora que hace tres años inició su negocio de papelería. Ella esta casada y tiene cuatro hijos, su esposo tiene que trabajar fuera de la ciudad, es por eso que ella sola maneja su negocio. Inició su negocio ante la necesidad de poder brindarles un mejor futura a sus hijos.

Esta solicitando un crédito por $ 475 USD a pagar en un plazo de 5-10 meses, para abastecerse de mercancía y poder ofrecer un buen surtido a sus clientes ahora con el inicio del regreso a clases de los niños.

loans.use: Merchandise

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
ENGLISH

Eleven years ago Martha and her husband started a small grocery store in order to give a better future to their family, they have six children. They started with the support of a supplier and now they have been growing on their own.

The store is located in a low income zone, lots of people know it and prefer it, and this is why Martha is requesting a loan of $925 USD. She plans to pay this loan back in a term of 4-8 months. And she will use this loan in order to buy merchandise and provide a better service to their clients.

ESPAÑOL

Hace once años que Martha y su esposo iniciaron un pequeño negocio de venta de abarrotes, con el fin de poder ofrecerle un mejor futuro a sus hijos. Su familia esta compuesta por ellos y seis hijos. Iniciaron con el crédito que les daba un proveedor y poco a poco han ido creciendo en su negocio.

Su tienda esta ubicada en una zona muy popular y la gente ya la conoce y la prefiere, es por eso que solicita un préstamo por $925 USD a pagar en un plazo de 4-8 meses, para poder surtir mejor su negocio y seguir ofreciendo un buen servicio a sus clientes.

loans.use: Merchandise

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Adibu Christine is responsibly married woman with a total of 5 children in her family. She came to Kampala in 1997 in one of the worst moments of her life experience is when more than 50 people were killed instantly in one day. This immediately prompted her abrupt migration to Kampala which led to her settlement in the Acholi Quarters.

While in Kampala things have not been so fine as there was no source of income to sustain her family. She then started selling ground nut paste around the locality of Acholi Quarter. When ground nut paste was not contributing enough towards her well being due to a rise in the cost of living, she shifted to rock quarrying and eventually acquired her own pit.

By God’s grace, she was introduced to life in Africa Organization which is like heaven to her. The difficulties which she experienced in feeding, renting, paying school fees are reduced which made life very fair and meaningful to her. Her main objective is to generate income that she may get enough to construct a permanent family house in the village if situation normalize in Northern Uganda.

Below is her budget:

BUDGET: 800,000/=

Renting land where bricks are to be laid 10,000/=

monthly-for 3 months – 30,000/=

Laying 10,000 bricks first at the rate of 30/= 300,000/=

Building Furnace for burning at 200,000/=

Fire wood for burning bricks 3 trips full truck at 100,000/=

Transport = 30,000/=

Water and labour – 70,000/=

1 new drum – 30,000/=

2 hoes plus handles – 10,000/=

Brick molder 4 at 30,000/=

loans.use: For brick laying

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lenders to Life in Africa borrowers in Uganda,

On behalf of Life in Africa's WE Center Kampala community I offer an apology for the irregularities in posting our borrower repayments and journal updates to the Kiva website over the past several months. In an effort to model a high standard of the transparency we operating in Africa should uphold online, this rather long message contains details that are relevant to helping you understand what's already happened, and what's happening now in the Life in Africa community with regard to this issue. Rest assured, Kiva staff are aware of these issues and some have personally met, face to face, a number of the personalities involved. We at LiA feel it's now high time to let you - our valued lenders - in on the sensitive nature of the challenges we've been dealing with.

In September 2006, some LiA community members tasked to manage the loan program and the Invisible Children bracelet campaign resigned amidst accusations of mismanagement from other members in the Life in Africa community. In the process, which was painful but arguably very healthy for the community in important ways, a laptop was stolen that included the records for both programs, the WE Center was closed for 2 weeks, and management of the invisible children project shifted to another site, taking 35 (of 80) Life in Africa members involved in the project with them to be full time employees. Among the staff lost during all the disruption at that time included 4 of 7 people trained to process and manage LiA member loans. Those who were left with loans training were heaped with mountains of new community management responsibilities on their plates. Everything related to the loans program seemed upside down and got out of synch for a while.

Most LiA borrowers experienced a 1-3 month period after the September events when payments due to them from the Invisible Children bracelet project were delayed. Many fell into arrears on their loans at that time. In most (but not all) of those cases, those arrears have now been paid up to date. However, in the wake of September's disruption, the paper files for the loan program were also left in disarray and the computerized records were gone. It took over 3 months for David Ewaku, a Life in Africa Board Member, to reconstruct the records and get the partnerships with Kiva (esp. online) and Invisible Children somewhat back on track, so that by January 2007 loan payments were coming in smoothly again.

Unfortunately, part of why it took so long was that David fell very ill and has been in and out of hospital since November. By then, however, we had hired a recent MBA grad with experience in microfinance as full time accounts manager for the Life in Africa community. Yet another disaster - the new accounts manager took over David's updated loan program records, and proceeded through professional incompetence to make a complete mess of them over the next 4 months. She resigned in mid-March 2007 after receiving a warning letter from the community operations team about her performance. We now find ourselves consulting 3 different sources of information that are riddled with holes and mistakes in order to get an accurate picture of what our borrowers have actually paid.

After a recent telephone discussion with Kiva staff about the apparent arrears in our loan portfolio, and with me hosting meetings in my home and participating in an advisory team for organizing Kiva's forthcoming ground-truthing efforts in East Africa this past week, we at LiA have been feeling a very keen sense of urgency about updating our payments on the Kiva website. Luckily, the community has Grace - our star community leader/borrower who is featured in the PBS Frontline segment about Kiva. Over the past 2 years, she has dedicated her heart and soul to uplifting Life in Africa's communities in both Kampala and Gulu. Though she is no accountant, Grace Ayaa has now committed herself to taking the LiA loan program's administrative challenges by the horns.

Over the past 2 weeks Grace has been working with a small group of community members to figure out how to reconstruct the community's loan program records, so that more than one person understands the process that's been used and everyone can agree on the final updated report. I can see she is very determined to do this transparently and am grateful on behalf of the LiA community to Grace for the leadership she's investing in getting our payment and loan tracking system straight and systemized once and for all. In fact, she had hoped to finish everything before leaving for a short trip to Gulu this morning. Instead, Grace and her group of committee members have asked me to appeal directly for lenders' patience. They feel that getting this sorted out right means it should not be approached in haste - they need more time to talk to the borrowers one by one to compare their records & recollections with the office records to get an accurate final picture of where each member stands.

PLEASE NOTE: To avoid that ALL of our members' online records are negatively affected any further by this internal administrative crisis, we are today marking all scheduled member loan payments as paid up to this month on the Kiva website. The amount paid on each account has been determined by the Kiva bulk-payments feature as the scheduled amount outstanding due to Kiva. Our community has, after all, guaranteed that each of these loans will be fully repaid to the lenders, regardless of each borrower's actual performance. Nonetheless, once we have all of this sorted out, we will update all of you (hopefully with next month's payments) on the accurate situation for your borrower with a link to the full and actual member repayment records for all loans guaranteed by the LiA community in 2006. In the cases where payments posted on Kiva were already up to date, I have posted a $1 payment to be able to alert all of our lenders to this message.

I humbly hope you can forgive us at LiA for not communicating with lenders earlier about the challenges we've faced in keeping the payments on Kiva accurately recorded, and thank you for your continued patience as the community works in good faith to get the mess sorted out. It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!

The total amount LiA has repaid to Kiva for this loan is now equivalent to payments received by LiA from the borrower. Visit LifeInAfrica.com/kiva/2006loans.htm to view the current repayment status of all Kiva loans disbursed at Life in Africa in 2006. A journal update about this particular borrower's performance is next on our Kiva reporting agenda - thanks for your patience!
Christine has successfully  finished paying back her loan. She has no default at all, sorry for any inconvenience caused by our late payment posting.

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard O. is a member of ‘Life in Africa’ and works with the invisible children bracelet project as a repairer.

Richard (28) came from the District of Pader and now lives at the Acholi Quarters with his wife and son of 2 years. He was forced to leave his home in the north due to the insurgency there. His camp where he had initially taken refuge was attacked by the rebels and that prompted his movement into the capital city where he has now lived for the past two years.

Richard’s story is one that has a real success behind it. He just started of at the stone quarry where everyone was actually getting their daily bread and later got a chance of joining life in Africa, this brought great change to his life. He has managed to start saving for his vision project which he feels is a video showroom, which is still lacking in the area. When he adds some more money onto what he has saved, he will be able to achieve now. He therefore seeks a loan of 800,000/= for this project . He will be able to pay this back in 12 months at the rate of 80,000/= a month, and below is the budget for this money. (This business is mainly done in evening so he can handle). Though he also have a brother who is willing to help him incase there is need to open early.

Screen 4” 350,000/=

Deck (video) 150,000/=

Amplifier 100,000/=

Generator 200,000/=

Total: 800,000/=

Other items like a pair of shelter speakers, tapes, fan and will be catered for through his savings.

loans.use: Buying Equipment for a video Show

payments.comment: Richard has only managed to make a few payments on his loan over recent months. His wife became ill when she was pregnant, and there were complications which required surgery. The medical bills have been overwhelming, but Richard continues to bring a few shillings when he can. This payment represents the balance on Richard's loan repaid to Kiva by Life in Africa, who will continue to collect the loan from Richard over time.

loans.name: Molly

texts.en:
K. Molly is an active member of Life in Africa who though looks to be almost living in her evening of life but but still capable of looking after her four children without the help of her husband who is actually more aged than her. And to make it worse, he is sick which means that out of the four children, her husband is moreless the fifth child! previously she has been doing charcoal business as the only source of income and she was left destitute because the little she got was spenton the four children and nothing was left for saving.

She is abit happy that since she joined Life in Africa six months ago, there is hope for better life as she is partly working with invisible children bracelet maker and with the help of a loan she is planning to restart her charcoal business because she has experience in it and her son is ready help her attend to the business. To do this businees Molly needs 500,000/= that she wishes to repay in 12 months at a rate of 50,000/=.

Below is her budget:

25 bags of charcoal @ 15,000/= ........375,000/=

Rental for the stall 4 months @ 30,000/=...120,000/=

Others ...................................5,000/=

Total...................................500.000/=

loans.use: Charcoal business
